loans.name: Porch

texts.en: Mrs. Porch K. lives in Kakaoh village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Ngaol Ngen, are farmers who own a plot of land where they cultivate rice. This couple has three children, one of whom is employed at the Thai border, while another is employed in India, and the remaining is attending the local school. Although this family’s members have differenct careers they don't earn enough income to support their needs. Now Mrs. Porch K. is requesting a loan to buy a motorbike for her family. Her husband is presented in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her family.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Gantugs

texts.en: Gantugs is a 34 year old divorced mother of two children who lives in a house in the Bayanhongor province of Mongolia. Her two children, 14 and 10, both attend a local secondary school while Gantugs runs a machinery part retail business out of a shipping container in the local market. She began her business in 2000 with working capital of 3,000,000 tugrugs, and since then she has grown her business operations and established herself in the business community. Her working capital now exceeds 10,000,000 tugrugs, and she credits part of her success to her accounting training. She says, “I want to have a warm, safe working environment as well as save up money for my children’s education.” Gantugs is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrugs loan in order to purchase machinery parts from Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia.

loans.use: To purchase machinery parts.

loans.name: Lanie

texts.en:
Lanie M. is from the town of Quezon, San Isidro. She is 41 years old, married, and has four school-aged children.

Lanie owns and operates a business of selling toys. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 1,000 PHP weekly.

In 2009, Lanie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used as additional capital for business improvement. She wants to purchase additional products to sell to be able to increase her income. This loan will be her first loan taken out from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 


About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.


 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Touch

texts.en:
Mrs. Touch R. is a villager in Rolus village in Takeo province. She is a Khmer cake seller. Her husband, Mr. Chhouk Mann, is a farmer who owns a 2-hectare (5-acre) piece of land on which he cultivates rice. Aside from this plantation, he is a duck breeder.

With his careers, Mrs. Touch R.’s husband faces some problems in his production and in his poultry business. Now, Mrs. Touch R. is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer, pesticides, and duck feed.

Mrs. Touch R. is 50 years old and the mother of three children who are attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticides, and duck feed for her husband's businesses

loans.name: Koeun

texts.en: Mrs. Koeun E. lives in Tuol Kandal village in Takeo province. She is a seller. Her husband, Mr. En Satha Vong, is a farmer who owns 3-hectar field of land to cultivate rice. Aside from this plantation, he is a construction worker. In his plantation, he faces an obstacle because he does not have enough money to buy fertilizers, pesticides, and to pay for plowing on the rice farming. Thus, Mrs. Koeun E. decided to request for a loan for this purpose. She is 25 years old and the mother of two children, one of whom is attending the local school while the other is too young to work or study. Her husband is presented in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, pesticides, and to pay for plowing on the rice farming.

loans.name: Gulgul

texts.en:
Gulgul is 30 years old and lives with her husband and two children in the Bayan-Ulgii province of western Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her two children, aged 7 and 6, both attend a local secondary school while her husband operates a transportation business.

Gulgul operates a dairy retail business. She began her business in 2006 and would like to rent a stall in the local market in the future so that she can increase her profits. She and her husband both work very hard to provide for their children and she would like to be able to build a house soon so that the family can live more comfortably.

Gulgul is requesting a 400,000 tugrug loan in order to purchase milk for her business.

loans.use: To purchase milk for her business

loans.name: Ronalyn

texts.en:
Ronalyn M. is from the town of Quezon San Isidro. She is 31 years old, married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Ronalyn owns and operates a bakery, selling a variety of baked goods in the local community. Ronalyn earns approximately 4500 weekly PHP a month.

In 2009, Ronalyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ronalyn is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP to purchase additional cooking ingredients. This loan will be her first from ASKI.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 
--------------------------------
About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: Purchase additional cooking ingredients.

loans.name: Edhmie

texts.en: Edhmie T. is from the village of Danao. She is 23 years old, is married, and has three infant children. Edhmie owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale. She is just starting this business. In 2006, Edhmie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from PMPC. Edhmie is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase pig feed and other supplies. This loan will be her 5th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase pig feed and other supplies

loans.name: Samith

texts.en: Samith S. is a 65 year old rice farmer who lives in Ank Prasat village in Takeo province.  She needs some money to buy a second cow for plowing.  Samith is a widow with four children; three are employed in a garment factory and the other attends a local school.

loans.use: Buy a cow for plowing.

loans.name: Humar

texts.en:
O. is 53 years old man who lives with his wife and five children in the Bayan-Ulgii province of Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a nomadic tent. His two oldest sons help with the family business while his daughters study at a university. 

O. operates a transportation service. He began his business in 1993 after working for several years as a driver for a private company. Besides transporting people and their goods, he also transports coal where he can sell it for a profit.  

He says, “I want to buy two more trucks for my sons in order for them to have their own transport services.” 

O. is requesting a 1,500,000 tugrug (~$1050) loan to purchase parts for his truck and to purchase coal to sell in Ulaanbaatar.

loans.use: Purchase spare parts for his truck and coal.

loans.name: Spider Group

texts.en:
Yasimin M., age 46, is married with two children, ages 30 and 26.  She has a business selling different items such as eggs, water, juice, soda and groundnuts, and she is able to earn a monthly profit of around $262.

This will be Yasmin’s first loan, called a motisha loan, from Tujijenge Tanzania.  Yasmin hopes to obtain a loan to increase her capital.
\t
Yasimin will share this loan with her loan group, which totals 15 members. The members of the group hold each other accountable in paying back the loan.  In the picture, Yasimin is first on the left front row.

loans.use: To increase her capital

loans.name: Modesta

texts.en: Modesta L. is from the village of Danao. She is 50 years old, is married, and has four school-aged children. Modesta owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She is just starting this business. In 2008, Modesta joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Modesta is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 2nd from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. loans.name: Oyunchimeg

texts.en:
Oyunchimeg is 40 years old and lives with her 20-year-old son in the Bayanhongor province of Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her son attends university and her husband helps Oyunchimeg with the family business, a grocery retail business.

Oyunchimeg began her business in 1999 in a shipping container at a local market. Since then, she has managed and grown her business very well and was able to move from the shipping container into a grocery shop. She hopes to operate her business for a very long time and to keep growing it as much as possible.

Oyunchimeg is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug loan in order to purchase a large amount of food products for her shop.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of food products for her shop

loans.name: Marina

texts.en:
Marina sells electrical goods - batteries, light bulbs, extension cords, etc., at Angolenko market in Zaporozhye city. She has been in this business for eight years. During this time she was able to develop her business well and gain many repeat clients and reliable suppliers. Today she has four kiosks where she sells her inventory.

Marina would like to receive a loan of 7,700 UAH to increase her assortment. She is a kind and friendly person. She lives with her husband and a small son.

loans.use: To increase her assortment

loans.name: Akar

texts.en:
Akar M. is 37 years old and married. Her husband is a mechanic. She has four children in school. Akar is currently in the business of selling fresh vegetables at market. She is requesting a loan to stock bags of maize flour to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.
About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services. These programs are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs, as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock bags of maize flour to sell.

loans.name: Hosiyat

texts.ru: Бадалова Хосият проживает в городе Вахдат. Возраст 65 лет. Вдова, имеет 4 детей. Хосият более 20 лет проработала по специальности, "кассиром". Потом Хосият решила начать свое дело и она открыла продуктовый магазин рядом с домом. Этим видом деятельности занимается более 9 лет. Кредит просит для увеличения товараоборота.
texts.en:
Hosiyat B. lives in the city of Vahdat. She is 65 years old, a widow and has 4 children. Hosiyat had worked as a cashier for over 20 years. Then, Hosiyat decided to start her own business and opened a food store near her house. She has been involved in this business for over 9 years. She is requesting a loan in order to increase product turnover.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Bisoboka Group 1, Lugazi

texts.en: N. Margaret is the leader of her lending group in Lugazi. She is a hard working and devoted lady with a business of selling matooke “green bananas” from Buwundo and Kizigo trading centres. She is a single mother with 2 children and she takes care of her other siblings, and she is grateful that the loans have helped her cope. She buys her matooke from the trucks and from the farmers in her surrounding villages and this helps her to have enough stock for her customers which is of good quality. She needs a loan to be able to stock more bunches of matooke to her stall since this will give her more profits after the sales to cater for other needs.

loans.name: Samson

texts.en: Samson sells crates of drinks at retail prices to his customers. He loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that he has with his customers. He is 29 years old and single without children. He is a very determined and hard-working man. He is a LAPO client. The Lift Above Poverty Organization is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. He has been in this business for six years. He is requesting a loan in the amount of NGN100,000 to purchase more crates of drinks to sell. He thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of drinks to sell

loans.name: Uranchimeg

texts.en: Uranchimeg is a 46-year-old divorced mother of three who lives in the Arkhangai province of Mongolia. She and her children live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her daughter, 23, is a teacher, her oldest son, 21, is a dancer and her youngest son, 18, attends university. Uranchimeg operates a plank and timber retail business in her town which she started in 2000 with working capital of 15,000 tugrugs (~10 USD). She quickly gained experience and expanded her business steadily in the nine years since. Now her working capital exceeds 3,000,000 tugrugs (~2100 USD). She hopes to keep expanding her business in the future in order to provide for her children. She is requesting a 1,500,000 tugrug (~1050 USD) loan in order to purchase a large amount of planks and timber for her business.

loans.use: to purchase a large amount of wood.

loans.name: Umujuma

texts.en:
Umujuma H. is currently in the business of selling rice, maize flour, beans and other products in a market and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of rice and beans to sell.  Umujuma is 39 years old and is married with a husband who is a security guard. She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a rice store.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Purchase more bags of rice and beans to sell.

loans.name: Tetyana

texts.en: Tetyana is divorced with three children. She sells baby carriages and other children's articles. Tetyana started this business 8 years ago. At that time she was able to purchase just a few items for sale. Today she's got two business locations - one at the market and the other at a department store - where she offers her clients a large variety of baby carriages and other children's products. Tetyana would like to borrow 17,000 UAH to purchase more for her inventory. Having three children she knows well what children need and offers such products to her clients. Tetyana's goal is to develop her business further and help her children to get a college education.

loans.use: to purchase more inventories

loans.name: Forever Living Group

texts.en:
Thomas M., age 36, is married and has one 4-year-old child.  He has had a business making telephone repairs for four years now and he is able to earn a monthly profit of around $419.

This will be Thomas’s first loan, called a motisha loan, from Tujijenge Tanzania.  Thomas hopes to obtain a loan to buy software, a computer and a blower.
	
Thomas will share this loan with his loan group, which totals 16 members. The members of the group hold each other accountable in paying back the loan.  In the picture, Thomas is the man in a red T-shirt.

loans.use: To buy software, a computer and a blower

loans.name: Munkhtsolmon

texts.en: A. Munkhtsolmon is 27 years old and lives with his wife and infant son in Arkhangai province, Mongolia. He and his family live in a traditional Mongolian housing tent called a “ger”. His wife is currently unemployed and stays at home to look after their young one. Munkhtsolmon operates a  transportation service in his town. He transports people around his local area using his car as a taxi. Munkhtsolomon started his business in 2000 after purchasing his car for 1,500,000 tugrugs (~1050 USD). Since then, he has stablized his business and built a reputation as a reliable driver. Today, his working capital exceeds 7,500,000 tugrugs (~5300 USD). Munkhtsolmon hopes to continue his success in the future. He is very energetic man and is very passionate about achieving his goals. He says, “I want to buy a bus to expand my business in the future.” Munkhtsolmon is requesting a 1,500,000 tugrug (~1050 USD) loan to purchase auto parts for his car.

loans.use: to purchase auto parts for his car.

loans.name: Rejina

texts.en:
Rejina W. sells groundnut paste, beans and tomatoes and is requesting a loan to buy more groundnuts to make paste to sell. Rejina is 36 years old and is married to a soldier. She has six children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a permanent house.

About BRAC: BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services. The programs are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more groundnuts to make paste to sell

loans.name: Amarbat

texts.en:
B. Amarbat operates a meat trading business in his town. He is 43 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Uvs province, in western Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian housing tent. His three children (two sons and a daughter) all attend a local secondary school.

Amarbat currently owns 250 sheep, 80 goats, 10 cows and 8 horses which he raises and uses to supply his business. He purchases new animals every fall and sells their meat during the spring when it is most profitable. It is quite a large task to take care of all the animals, but Amarbat has help. His wife and children all help out by tending to the animals at home.

Amarbat started his business in 2000 and has become quite successful in his trade. He continues to grow his business and has plans to have his own farm and improve his breeding practices in the near future. He works very hard to support his family and says, "I want my children to be well educated so they can lead happy lives.” He is requesting a 1,500,000 tugrug loan to purchase more livestock for his business.

loans.use: To purchase more livestock

loans.name: Louise

texts.fr: K. Louise est née le 26 octobre 1960 au Bénin. Louise vit depuis 40 ans à Fidjrossè à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à TCHICOHOSSOU Claude un conducteur de poids lourds, Louise est mère d’un enfant qui est scolarisé. Le couple a sept autre enfants à leur charge. La famille vit ensemble à Fidjrossè. Louise vient en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille. Louise n’a fait que l’école primaire. Il y a environs 25 ans que Louise vend des bois de chauffage et du charbon de bois, à son domicile. Louise s’approvisionne dans les forêts du Bénin, et aussi à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Louise a obtenu déjà trois crédits à ALIDé, crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. Louise désire agrandir davantage son activité afin de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle, mais elle ne dispose pas suffisamment de fonds pour y parvenir. C’est la raison pour laquelle Louise sollicite un quatrième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Louise K. was born October 26, 1960 in Bénin. Louise has lived in Fidjroose a Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin, for 40 years. Married to Claude Tchicohossou, a heavy truck driver, Louise has one child who is in school. The couple takes care of seven other children. The family lives together in Fidjrosse. Louise helps her husband support the family. She did not go to elementary school.

About 25 years ago, Louise started selling firewood and charcoal out of her home. Louise stocks up in the forests of Bénin and in Dantokpa, the international market of Bénin. Louise has already received three loans from ALIDé, loans which she repaid in full. Louise would like to grow her business more in order to better satisfy her customers, but she does not have enough funds to manage this alone. For this reason, she is asking for a fourth loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of Wholesale Firewood

loans.name: Faith

texts.en: Faith sells crates of drinks at retail prices to her customers in Agbor, Delta state. She is 46 years old and married with four children. Her youngest child is 18 years old. Her husband is a commercial driver, and he also supports the home. She has been in this business for five years. She is a very focused businesswoman. She is a LAPO client. The Lift Above Poverty Organization is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. She is requesting a loan in the amount of NGN 100,000 to purchase more crates of drinks to sell. She thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of drinks to sell

loans.name: Baatarsuren

texts.en: B. Baatarsuren is 33 years old and lives in Arkhangai province in central Mongolia. She lives with her husband in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian housing tent. Baatarsuren operates a small grocery trading business in her town. She started her business in 2006 with working capital of 50,000 tugrugs (~35 USD) and has built a consistent operation over the last two years. Today, she has a large customer base that appreciates her quality food products and her working capital now exceeds 400,000 tugrugs (~280 USD). She attributes this success to her good management and accounting skills. Baatarsuren hopes to continue her success in the future and says, “I hope to soon expand my business to increase my sales.” She is requesting a 380,000 tugrug (~270 USD) loan to purchase groceries for her shop.

loans.use: to purchase groceries to resell

loans.name: Sarvorat

texts.ru: Каримова Сарворат проживает в городе Вахдат. Возраст 51 год. Замужем, имеет 2 детей. Имеет средне специальное образование. Сарворат имеет собственный магазин, где более 7 лет торгует техникой. Муж находится в России на заработках. Кредит просит для увеличения товараоборота.
texts.en:
Sarvorat K. lives in the city of Vahdat. She is 51 years old, married and has 2 children. She has secondary technical education. Sarvorat owns a store, where she has been selling electronics for over 7 years. Her husband currently works in Russia. She is requesting a loan in order to increase goods turnover.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing goods turnover

loans.name: Iponi

texts.en:
Iponi V. is currently in the business of selling air time on all mobile networks in south sudan and is requesting a loan to purchase mobile phones and more air time to sell.  Iponi is 30 years old and is married with a husband that is a police man. She has 2 children and her children do not go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase mobile phones and more air time to sell

loans.name: Banzragch

texts.en: D. Banzragch is 61 years old and lives with his wife and son in Ulaanbaatar, the largest city and capital of Mongolia. His son is 21 years old and currently attends university in the city. His wife helps out with managing the family business. Banzragch operates a small grocery shop in his town. He started his business in 2004 with capital of 400,000 tugrugs (~280 USD) after receving a loan from Xacbank, Kiva's Mongolian partner MFI. He took advantage of this loan and used it to successfully grow his business into a stable operation. Today, his working capital exceeds 1,000,000 tugrugs (~700 USD). Banzragch hopes further his business again with a new loan. He says, “I want to expand my product variety to attract new customers and I one day hope to own my own trading center." He is requesting an 800,000 tugrug (~560 USD) loan to purchase groceries for his business.

loans.use: to purchase groceries to resell

loans.name: Famous

texts.en: Famous sells tailoring materials to make a living in Agbor, Delta state. He loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that he has with his customers. He is 39 years old and married with three children. He is an honest and faithful LAPO client. The Lift Above Poverty Organization is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. He has been in this business for seven years. He is requesting a loan in the amount of NGN 100,000 to purchase more tailoring materials to sell. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring materials to sell

loans.name: Bayanjargal

texts.en: Bayanjargal is 48 years old and lives with his wife and 20-year-old daughter in the Arkhangai province of Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His daughter attends university and his wife helps Bayanjargal with the family business. He operates a consumer goods retail business and a transportation service. He began his business in 2000 with working capital of 300,000 tugrugs (~210 USD) and since then he has established himself within the business community and his working capital now exceeds 5,000,000 tugrugs (~3500 USD). Bayanjargal says, “I want to expand and improve my business in the future.” He is requesting a 1,500,000 tugrug (~1050 USD) loan in order to purchase consumer products and fuel for his business.

loans.use: to purchase consumer products to sell and fuel his transportation business

loans.name: Laurette

texts.fr: A. Laurette est née le 11 Novembre 1979 au Bénin. Laurette vit depuis une dizaine d’année, à Cadjèhoun à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à OROBIYI Afred, un imprimeur, Laurette est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Laurette a un autre enfant à charge, en plus de ses enfants. Tous les enfants vivent avec leurs parents à Cadjèhoun. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Laurette n’a pas été à l’école. C’est depuis 18 ans que Laurette mène comme activité, la vente de produits de SOBEBRA (Société Béninoise de Brasserie), en face du Ministère des Finances. Laurette vend divers autres produits (lait, savons, cigarettes, eau minérale, huile d'arachide, etc.). Laurette s’approvisionne dans les dépôts de boissons à Cotonou, et à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant bénéficié de deux crédits à ALIDé et qui ont été bien remboursés. C’est dans l’optique d’augmenter son fonds de roulement et d’élever le niveau de son activité afin de mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle, que Laurette sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
A. Laurette was born on November 11, 1979 in Benin.  She has been living for about ten years in Cadjèhoun in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  Married to OROBIYI Afred, a printer, she is the mother of three children who are all in school.  She has another child to support in addition to her own.  The children all live with their parents in Cadjèhoun.  The couple is covering family expenses jointly.  Laurette did not attend school.  For eighteen years, she has been running a business selling SOBEBRA products (Société Béninoise de Brasserie, a beverages company of Benin) across from the Finance Ministry.  She sells a variety of other goods (milk, soaps, cigarettes, mineral water, peanut oil, etc.)  She stocks up from beverage outlets in Cotonou and from Dantokpa, the international market of Benin.  She is a previous ALIDé client having benefited from two ALIDé loans, which have been repaid.  With regard to augmenting her working capital and to raising her level of business, in order to respond better to the demands of her customers, Laurette is requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying boxes of canned drinks and liquor

loans.name: Chuluuntsetseg

texts.en:
U. Chuluuntsetseg is 29 years old and lives with her husband and son in Arkhangai province, Mongolia. She and her family live in a traditional Mongolian housing tent called a “ger”. Her son, Ganbold, is 5 years old, and is in kindergarten.

Chuluuntsetseg operates a clothing trading business in her town. She started her business in 2006 with working capital of 100,000 tugrugs (~70 USD) and has established her business well in the community over the last three years. She has gained great experience as a businesswoman and has built a loyal customer base. Today, her working capital exceeds 5,000,000 tugrugs (~3500 USD).

Chuluuntsetseg is very hardworking and attributes her success to her good accounting and excellent communication skills. She is optimistic about the future and says, “I am planning to soon expand my business to increase my sales." She is requesting a 3,500,000 tugrug (~2460 USD) loan to purchase clothing items to sell in her business.

loans.use: To purchase clothing to sell

loans.name: Apoko

texts.en:
Apoko P. is currently in the business of selling fresh vegetables in a market. She is requesting a loan to buy fish and groundnuts to make paste to sell. Apoko is 30 years old and married; her husband is an accountant. She has 4 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for settlement.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services. These programs are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy fish and groundnuts to make paste to sell.

loans.name: Darhijav

texts.en:
Darhijav is a 55-year-old widow who lives with her 23-year-old daughter in the Khovd province of Mongolia. She and her daughter live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, and her older children are living and working on their own.

Darhijav operates a food café in a local market and a grocery shop near her home. She operates her café during the winter months and her grocery shop during the summer months. She began her business in 2000, and since then, has achieved a great reputation amongst her customers and suppliers. She would like to open a second hand shop in the future in order to reach more customers and grow her income. She says, “All of my children are living on their own except for my youngest daughter. I want her to be an educated young lady with a happy life.”

Darhijav is requesting an 800,000 tugrug (~560 USD) loan in order to purchase a large amount of foods for her café.

loans.use: To purchase food for her cafe

loans.name: Chucks

texts.en: Chucks sells electronics and electrical materials at retail prices to his customers. He loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that he has with his customers. He is 40 years old and married with four children. His eldest child is 9 years old. His children are still dependent on him, and they go to school. He is a hard-working man. He is an honest and faithful LAPO client. The Lift Above Poverty Organization is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. He has been in this business for a long time. He is requesting a loan in the amount of NGN 100,000 to purchase more electronics and electrical materials to sell. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more electronics and electrical materials to sell

loans.name: Chance

texts.en:
Chance M. is currently in the business of selling beer and local alcohol beverages. She is requesting a loan to stock more crates of beer and sodas to sell. Chance is 25 years old and single. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a permanent house.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services. These programs are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more crates of beer and sodas to sell

loans.name: Ivan

texts.en:
Ivan's business is to sell food in bulk. He has two business locations. One is in Striy city, where he mainly sells flour and sugar in bags to small local retail stores. At the other location, which is in small village, he sells same products but to individual people, who prefer to buy sugar and flour in bags. This helps them to save some money as well as make sure they have enough food for several months.

Ivan started this business 19 years ago. He has many repeat clients who buy from him. Ivan has good prices and offers transportation services using his private vehicle. Ivan would like to borrow 17,000 UAH to purchase 11 tons of flour. Ivan's business goal is to build his own storage place that he would not need to pay rent for. Ivan sponsors Christmas gifts for children in the village where he works.

loans.use: To purchase 11 tons of flour

loans.name: Enebish

texts.en: Enebish is a 40-year-old widow who lives with her 16-year-old son in the Arkhangai province of Mongolia. She and her son live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her son attends a local secondary school while Enebish operates a clothing retail business in her town. She began her business in 2006 with the help of a friend.  In 2008, she was able to take on the business by herself. When she began, her working capital was approximately 1,000,000 tugrugs (~$700 US). However, in the few years since she has begun, her business has grown quickly and now her working capital exceeds 3,200,000 tugrugs (~$2250 US). Because of her success, Enebish is able to pay for her son’s education and all of the family’s expenses. She says, “I want to expand my working space and improve my business.” Enebish is requesting a 4,000,000 tugrug (~$2800 US) loan to purchase a large amount of winter clothes to resell.

loans.use: To purchase winter clothes to resell

loans.name: Delphine

texts.fr: D. Delphine est née en 1964 au Bénin. Delphine vit depuis une dizaine d’année à Cadjèhoun à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à LAROU Nicolas un entrepreneur, Delphine est mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. Le couple a un autre enfant à charge, en plus de leurs enfants. La famille vit ensemble à Cadjèhoun. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Delphine n’a pas été à l’école. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants, Delphine vend de l’igname pilé accompagné de sauce d’arachide (un aliment bien aimé des béninois) en face du Ministère des Finances au Bénin. Delphine exerce cette activité depuis environs  10 ans. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Delphine s’approvisionne. Delphine est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà obtenu deux crédits auprès de l’institution, crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. Delphine sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé, afin d’agrandir davantage son activité et de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
D. Delphine was born in 1964 in Benin.  She has been living for about ten years in Cadjèhoun, in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  Married to LAROU Nicolas, an entrepreneur, she is the mother of four children who are all in school.  The couple has another child to support in addition to their own.  The family lives together in Cadjèhoun. The couple is covering family expenses jointly.  Delphine did not attend school.  To provide for her needs and those of her children, she sells pounded yams served with peanut sauce (a much-loved food of the Beninese people) across from the Finance Ministry in Benin.  She has been in this business for about ten years.  She stocks up from Dantokpa, the international market of Benin.  She is a previous ALIDé client having already had two loans from this micro-finance institution.  And the loans have indeed been repaid. Delphine is requesting a third loan from ALIDé in order to expand her business further and to satisfy her customers more.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying sacks of yams and sauce condiments (tomatoes, onions, chili peppers, etc.)

loans.name: Francisca

texts.es: Francisca D. L. D. R. D. 39 años D. edad, resiD. en Santiago Nonualco, departamento D. La Paz. Vive junto a su esposo y sus dos hijos menores D. edad los cuales se dedican a estudiar. Ella junto a su esposo poseen una venta D. productos lácteos en su propia casa, lo cual les generan buenas ganancias lo cual les permite solventar todos los gastos del hogar, a pesar D. esto, ellos desean poder construir un  garaje, lo cual no les es posible hasta la fecha, ya que las ganancias generadas no les ajusta para poder realizar este tipo D. trabajo en su casa. Es por esto que ellos solicitan un préstamo a través del cual puedan contar con el capital necesario para construirlo, esto con el fin D. tener más seguro el automóvil que posee, el cual lo utilizan para distribuir el queso con los diferentes clientes.
texts.en:
Francisca D. L. D. R. is 39 years old and lives in Santiago Nonualco, in the Department of La Paz. She lives with her husband and their two children, who are still young and attending school. Francisca and her husband operate a shop selling dairy products in their own home. The business generates a good income, allowing them to cover all of their household expenses. Nevertheless, they would like to build a garage, and this has not been possible until now, since the income from the business has not been sufficient to carry out this type of work in their home. For this reason, they are requesting a loan which will proviD. them with enough capital to construct the garage. Their aim is to proviD. better security for the car they own, which they use to distribute cheese to various customers.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Building a garage

location.town: Santiago Nonualco, departamento de La Paz

loans.name: Fretzel Liza

texts.en: Fretzel Liza B. is from the village of Banonong. She is 38 years old, is married, and has three school-aged children. Fretzel Liza owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP average per month. In 2008, Fretzel Liza joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell in her sari-sari (variety) store business. Fretzel Liza is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase pig feed and other supplies for her pig-raising activity. This loan will be her 3rd from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support her children’s education. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase pig feed and other supplies

loans.name: Oyunchimeg

texts.en: Oyunchimeg is a 43-year-old widow who lives with her two children in the Arkhangai province of Mongolia. She and her children live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her oldest son, 21, is in the army and her younger son, 20, attends university while Oyunchimeg operates a dairy retail business in her town. She began her business in 1995 with working capital of 50,000 tugrugs (~$35 US). Since then, she has gained a good reputation among her customers and her business has steadily grown so that her working capital now exceeds 800,000 tugrugs (~$575 US). She says, “I want to keep expanding and improving my business.” Oyunchimeg is requesting an 800,000 tugrug loan to purchase a large order of dairy products in order to increase her sales.

loans.use: To purchase more dairy products

loans.name: Jubeida

texts.en:
Jubeida A. currently sells beans, peas and maize flour, among other products.  She is requesting a loan to purchase bags of rice and maize flour to sell.  Jubeida is 30 years old and married to a businessman. She has 4 children who all go to school.  With the extra profits that will be generated from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a big shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase bags of rice and maize flour to sell.

loans.name: Valentine

texts.en:
Valentine sells groceries at retail prices to her customers. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers.  She is 44 years old, married with four children. Her youngest child is eight years old. Her children are still dependent on her and they go to school. She is a hard working woman. 

She is an honest and faithful LAPO client. The Lift Above Poverty Organization is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. She hopes for a loan amount to purchase more groceries to sell. She thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Najjembe Group 1, Lugazi

texts.en: Veronica L. is a hard-working and devoted lady with a vibrant business selling fruits and vegetables in the Najjembe market. She has a stall in the main market that is stocked with tomatoes, onions, mangoes, oranges, pineapples and other produce.  She buys fruit and vegetables mostly from farmers in the surrounding villages at a lower price than she pays at the big markets in Kampala and at farm trucks. Veronica is married with 8 children, as she takes care of her siblings in the village. Veronica needs a loan to be able to buy more produce for resale.

loans.use: Buying more produce to resell

loans.name: Tungalagtuul

texts.en: Tungalagtuul is 41 years old and lives with her husband and two children in the Arkhangai province of Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her two children, 13 and 7, both attend local schools while Tungalagtuul and her husband operate a clothes-making business in their town. She began her business in 2005 with working capital of 1,000,000 tugrugs (~$700 US) and after four years in operation, she has gained a lot of experience and many customers. Her working capital now exceeds 2,000,000 tugrugs (~$1400 US). She says, “I want to keep expanding and improving my business in the future.” She is requesting a 1,500,000 tugrug (~$1050 US) loan in order to purchase fabric and materials for her business.

loans.use: To purchase fabric and materials

loans.name: Jokudu

texts.en:
Jokudu L. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and beans, and she is requesting a loan to buy more bags of charcoal to sell. Jokudu is 34 years old and married; her husband is a soldier. She has 5 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a charcoal store.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services. These programs are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Najjembe Group 2, Lugazi

texts.en:
N. Teddy is the leader of her lending group in Lugazi. She is a widow with six children; three of them are at the University and three have completed their studies and have their own families.

Teddy has a restaurant in Najjembe that she has been running for a long time. She has been able to win many clients because of her experienced cooking and good customer care. Her customers are mostly the traders in the Najjembe market and truck drivers who rest in the area. Teddy usually buys her foodstuffs in large quantities at a less cost, and she wants to stock more foodstuffs for her restaurants.

loans.use: To buy more food stuffs to increase her stock

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica sells Nigerian cooked foods to make a living. She is a 45-year-old widow with five children. Her youngest child is 14 years old. She is a hard-working woman. 

She is also an honest and faithful LAPO client. The Lift Above Poverty Organization is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. She hopes for a loan to purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell

loans.name: Buseina

texts.en:
Buseina R. is currently in the business of selling onions and tomatoes in the market. She is requesting a loan to purchase fresh vegetables and fruits to sell. Buseina is 30 years old and married; her husband is a policeman. She has 4 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services. These programs are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase fresh vegetables and fruits to sell

loans.name: Nyoka

texts.en:
Nyoka M. is currently in the business of selling dried fish, beans, and sugar. She is requesting a loan to buy fresh fish and more dried fish to sell. Nyoka is 28 years old and married; her husband is a soldier. She has 3 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for renting.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services. These programs are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy fresh and dried fish to sell

loans.name: Benedicta

texts.en: Benedicta sells bags of poultry feed at retail and wholesale prices to her customers. She is 35 years-old and married with five children. Her husband sells timber to support the home. She is an honest and faithful Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) client.  Kiva partner LAPO is committed to improving lives in Africa particularly in Nigeria.  Benedicta has been in this business for a long time and she is a very focused business woman with strong determination. She is requesting a loan of  NGN 50,000 to purchase more bags of poultry feed to sell. She thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase bags of poultry feed.

loans.name: Alita

texts.en: Alita M. is from the village of Lower Dicayas. She is 56 years old and is single. Alita owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Alita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. Alita is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase pig feed and other supplies. This loan will be her 3rd from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase pig feed and other supplies

loans.name: Najjembe Group 3, Lugazi

texts.en:
W. Majeri is the leader of her lending group in Lugazi. She is a hardworking and devoted lady with a business of selling fruits and vegetables from Najjembe market on the Kampala–Jinja highway. She has been selling cabbages, avocados, oranges, pineapples, and greens for many years now and she is quick to admit that the loans have helped her have a variety. She is a married lady with children; all of them are old now and she cares only for her grandchildren. 

Majeri needs a loan to be able to stock her business with more produce for resale.

loans.use: To buy more fruits and vegetables for resale

loans.name: Claire

texts.fr: D. Claire est née le 12 Août 1959 et vit à Trokpocodji à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, depuis une dizaine d’année. Mariée à ADJA Maurice, Claire est mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. Claire a un autre enfant à charge. La famille vit ensemble à Trokpocodji à Cotonou. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Claire n’a fait que le cours primaire. Pour faire face à ses besoins quotidiens, Claire vend de la nourriture (riz, haricot, accompagné de sauce, etc.) en face du Ministère des Finances à Cotonou. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Claire s’approvisionne. Claire est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, qui rembourse bien ses crédits. Claire voudrait agrandir davantage son activité et mieux satisfaire sa clientèle. C’est la raison pour laquelle Claire sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
D. Claire was born on August 12, 1959, and she has been living in Trokpocodji in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, for about ten years.  Married to ADJA Maurice, she is the mother of four children who are all in school.  And she has another child to support.  The family lives together in Trokpocodji in Cotonou.  The couple is covering family expenses jointly.  Claire attended primary school only.  To address her day-to-day needs, she sells food (rice, beans, served with sauce, etc.) across from the Finance Ministry in Cotonou.  She stocks up from Dantokpa, the international market of Benin.  She is a previous ALIDé client who repays her loans.  She would like to expand her business further and to satisfy her customers more.  For these reasons, Claire is requesting a third loan from ALIDé. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying sacks of rice and beans and sauce condiments (tomatoes, onions, chili peppers, etc.)

loans.name: Valente Arrone

texts.pt:
Valente Arrone M. nasceu no Distrito de Bilene, Província de Gaza, sul de Moçambique, tem 50 anos de idade, casado e pai de 5 filhos de 23, 21, 18, 13 e 11 anos de idade, destes o mais velho já não estuda. Licenciado em psicologia e pedagogia pela Universidade pedagógica no ano de 2008. Vive na casa própria com a sua família e sustenta um neto que vive com ele.

Saiu de Bilene para a cidade de Maputo, afim de continuar com os seus estudos, mais tarde começa a trabalhar no Distrito de Marracuene ainda na mesma província como docente. Exerce esta actividade a mais de 33 anos, faz um horário único das 7h as 12 horas e é do quadro do Ministério da Educação. Foi transferido para Boane onde veio a fixar a sua residência e vive neste local ate hoje. Tem um salário mensal de 12.900.00mt que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa algum na sua conta bancária.

Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku quando passava em frente do escritório onde decidiu aproximar e se informar das condições de acesso a crédito. Este é o seu 2º empréstimo no valor de 25.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (tintas, cimento, lava loiça, e portas interiores) para dar continuidade com a sua obra. O empréstimo anterior foi de 25.000.00mt para a mesma actividade.
 
 Futuramente gostaria de solicitar mais empréstimos para construir uma dependência no terreno da sua terra natal em Bilene Macia.
texts.en:
Valente Arrone M. was born in Bilene District, Gaza Province, in southern Mozambique. He is 50 years old, a married father of five children who are 23,21,18, 13 and 11 years old. The oldest child is no longer studying. Valente graduated from the teaching University with a degree in psychology and education in 2008. He lives with his family in his own house, and supports a grandson who lives with him.

He left Bilene for Maputo in order to continue his studies, and later started working as a teacher in Marracuene District. He performed this work for over 33 years and worked from 7am to 12 noon, following the Ministry of Education schedule. He was transferred to Boane where established his residence, and where he lives today. He earns a monthly salary of 12,900 MZN that he uses for household expenses while still saving some in his bank account.

He has never taken out a loan with another bank, and he learned about Hluvuku when he walked by their office and decided to learn more about the requirements for getting credit. This is his second loan in the amount of 25,000 MZN, with which he intends to buy construction materials (paint, cement, sink and interior doors) to complete his house. The previous loan was for 25,000 to do the same work.

In the future he would like to apply for additional loans in order to build a cottage on land in his home town in Bilene Macia.

Translated from Portuguese by David Kaisel, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase construction materials

loans.name: Mahoussi

texts.fr: G. Mahoussi est née en 1964 et réside depuis 9 ans à Akogbato à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à HASSOU Sossa, un militaire à la retraite, Mahoussi est mère de deux enfants. Tous les deux enfants sont scolarisés et vivent ensemble avec leurs parents à Akogbato. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Mahoussi n’a pas été à l’école. Pour faire face à ses besoins et assurer l’avenir de ses enfants, Mahoussi vend de la nourriture (pâtes de cossettes d’igname, accompagnée de sauce) en face du Ministère des Finances à Cotonou. Mahoussi exerce cette activité depuis environs 25 ans. C‘est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Mahoussi s’approvisionne. Mahoussi est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà obtenu deux crédits à ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés. Mahoussi sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé, afin d’augmenter son fonds de roulement et d’élever le niveau de son activité.
texts.en:
Mahoussi G. was born in 1964 and for the past 9 years has resided in the Akogbato district of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is married to Sossa HASSOU, a military retiree, and is the mother of two children. The children attend school and live with their parents in Akogbato. Both parents share support for the family. Mahoussi has not attended school. To meet her needs and ensure her children's future, Mahoussi has been selling food (dried yam paste, with sauce) in front of the Ministry of Finances in Cotonou. She has been performing this activity for the past 25 years, and gets her supplies from Dantokpa, Benin's international market. Mahoussi is an old customer of ALIDé, where she already obtained two loans, both of which were fully reimbursed. She now requests a third loan from ALIDé, to increase her working capital and the level of her activities.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy bags of dried yams and sauce ingredients (tomatoes, onions, chillies, etc.)

loans.name: Nailina Massingue

texts.pt:
Nailina Massingue nasceu no Distrito da Moamba, Província de Maputo, sul de Moçambique, tem 54 anos de idade, solteira e mãe de 3 filhos cuja as idades não as conhece, todos vão a escola. Não estudou porque os pais não deram prioridade a escola mais sim ao trabalho da machamba. Vive na casa própria com os seus filhos e não sustenta mais ninguém.

Saiu de Moamba para o Distrito Boane com os seus filhos após a separação com o seu marido em 1988. Trabalha como auxiliar de limpezas no Governo do Distrito de Boane a mais de 24 anos, conta também com um negócio próprio que desenvolve a mais de 25 anos. Vende mais cerveja adquirindo por 250.00mt a caixa e vende por 300.00mt. Consegue obter um rendimento de cerca de 1.000.00mt por semana e um salário de 2.500.00mt por mes que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa algum na sua conta bancária e através de Xitique (sistema tradicional de poupança rotativa). 

Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de seu vizinho que também é cliente desta instituição. Este é o seu 6º empréstimo no valor de 20.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar produtos (cerveja, refrescos, vinhos e outros) para aumentar a quantidade da sua mercadoria. Os empréstimos anteriores foram de 6.000.00mt, 10.000.00mt, 13.000.00mt, 20.000.00mt e 20.000.00mt todos para a mesma actividade.
 
 Futuramente gostaria de solicitar mais empréstimos para melhorar ainda mais o seu negócio e também para a aquisição de mobiliário para a casa.
texts.en:
Nailina Massingue was born in the District of Moamba, Maputo Province, south of Mozambique. She’s 54 years old. She’s a single mother of 3, although she doesn’t know their ages. All of them go to school. She didn’t receive an education because her parents prioritized working in the machamba (farm) over going to school. She lives in her own house with her children. She doesn’t support anybody else. She left Moamba to live in the District of Boane with her children after she separated from her husband in 1988. She’s been working as a custodian for the Government of the District of Boane for 24 years. She's also owned a shop for more than 25 years. She sells beer that she buys for 250.00mt a box and sells for 300.00mt. Her earnings reach around 1.000.00mt a week and her salary is 2.500.00mt a month, which goes toward household expenses. She even saves some to put on her bank account and through a traditional system of rotational savings called Xitique. She never requested for any from any other bank. She came to Hluvuku through a neighbor who's also a client of our organization. This is her 6th loan for an amount of 20.000.00mt. She will use the money to purchase items such as beer, soft drinks, wine and others to increase her stock. Her previous loans were for 6.000.00mt, 10.000.00mt, 13.000.00mt, 20.000.00mt and 20.000.00mt, all of the used for this same activity. (1 dollar = 28.51MT). In the future, she would like to request for more loans to improve her business and to buy furniture for her home.

Translated from Portuguese by Jimena Lopez, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase and sell beer, soft drinks, wine and others

loans.name: Sapakamapie Group

texts.en:
These are members of the 'Sapakamapie' group. They are small-scale businesspeople in the town of Magburaka in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of SLL 500,000 each in order to invest in their businesses. With the help of this loan, they can add more goods to their businesses, make more sales, earn better profit, and consequently improve the living standards of their families.

Salaymatu B. on the left of the photo is the leader of this group. Salaymatu was born in Magburaka town thirty-two years ago. She is married to a businessman and they have four children who are attending primary and secondary schools.

Salaymatu sells fried chicken and foofoo (cooked food made out of ground cassava). Salaymatu has been in this business for more than ten years now. With her share of this loan, she will buy a carton of chicken and a bag of foofoo.

loans.use: Buy a carton of chicken and a bag of foofoo

loans.name: Najjembe Group 2, Lugazi

texts.en: N. Teddy is the leader of her lending group in Lugazi. She is a widow with six children, three of whom attend University and three of whom have completed their studies and have their own families. Teddy has a restaurant in Najjembe that she has been running for a long time; she has been able to win many clients because of her experienced cooking and good customer care. Her customers are primarily traders in the Najjembe market and truck drivers who stop to rest in the area. Teddy usually buys her foodstuff in large quantities at a low cost, and she would like to stock more foodstuff for her restaurant.

loans.use: to buy more foodstuff for her restaurant

loans.name: Miguel Luis

texts.pt:
Miguel Luís G. nasceu na cidade de Maputo, Província de mesmo nome, sul de Moçambique, tem 49 anos de idade, casado e pai de 3 filhos de 24, 22 e 18 anos de idade, destes o do meio é que vai a escola. Fez 6ª classe do antigo sistema de educação, não continuou devido a falta de condições financeiras por parte dos progenitores. Vive na casa própria com a sua família e sustenta seu pai que vive na cidade de Maputo enviando dinheiro e produtos alimentares.

Saiu de Maputo para Beira em missão de serviço em 1983, no mesmo ano é transferido da Beira para Nampula norte de Moçambique para continuar com as suas actividades. Terminadas as actividades regressa a cidade capital, local onde reside actualmente. Trabalha na TCM (Transportes e Comunicações de Moçambique) como chefe dos recursos humanos desde 1982, onde faz 8 horas diárias. No tempo pós laboral desenvolve seu negocio por um período de 4h por dia, onde consegue um salário de 7.800.00 na empresa e no negocio cerca de 4.000.00mt por mes, que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa cerca de 1.500.00mt de vez em quanto na sua conta bancária. 

Já teve empréstimo no banco Millinium Bim, depois de terminar com o pagamento decidiu não continuar, conheceu a Hluvuku através de futebol quando arbitrava o campeonato nacional onde Hluvuku participou, e decidiu visitar a instituição. Este é o seu 2º empréstimo no valor de 20.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar produtos (óleo, ovos, leite, bebidas e outros) para aumentar a quantidade da sua mercadoria no seu estabelecimento. O empréstimo anterior foi de 12.000.00mt para a mesma actividade.
 
 Futuramente gostaria de solicitar mais empréstimos para melhorar a sua residência e para aplicar no seu negócio. Por isso compromete se a pagar devidamente este empréstimo para poderá aceder a outros no futuro.
texts.en:
Miguel Luís G. was born in the City and Province of Maputo, south of Mozambique. He’s 49 years old. He’s married and has 3 children, ages 24, 22 and 18. The middle child is currently going to school. He finished up to 6th grade of the old school system, but he couldn't continue because his parents had serious financial problems. He lives in his own house with his family and he also supports his father, who lives in the city of Maputo, sending him money and food. He left Maputo to go to Beira for a service mission in 1983. That same year he was transferred from Beira to Nampula, north of Mozambique to continue with his activity. Once his service was completed, he returned to the capital city, where he lives now. He’s worked for TCM (Mozambique Transportation and Communications) as HR Manager since 1982, 8 hours a day. After his day time job, he devotes around 4 hours a day to his business. He gets a 7.800.00 salary from his company and 4.000.00mt a month from his business, which he uses for household expenses. He saves around 1.500.00mt from time to time to put on his bank account. He received a loan from Millinium Bim bank, but after he finished his payments he decided to leave. He met Hluvuku through a soccer tournament where he was a referee and Hluvuku was participating, so he decided to visit our organization. This is his 2nd loan for an amount of 20.000.00mt, which he will use to buy products, such as oil, eggs, milk, drinks and others, to increase his stock. His previous loan was for 12.000.00mt which he used for this same activity. (1 dollar = 28.51MT) In the future he would like to request for more loans to make home improvements and to restock him business. For this reason, he’s committed to pay this loan in time and access to more money later.

Translated from Portuguese by Jimena Lopez, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy products, such as oil, eggs, milk, drinks and others

loans.name: Charity

texts.en: Charity sells groceries at retail prices to her customers. This is the high season for sales and she hopes to make more profits. She is 45 years-old and married with five children. Her husband is also a business man. She is an honest and faithful Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) client. Kiva partner LAPO is committed to improving lives in Africa, particularly in Nigeria.  She hopes for a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more groceries to sell. She thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries.

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en: Virginia G. is from the village of Olingan. She is 61 years old, is widowed, and has five adult children. Virginia owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over nine years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP average per month. In 2006, Virginia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. Virginia is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used to purchase pig feed and other supplies, and as additional capital for her other business which is selling fish. This loan will be her 8th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase pig feed and other supplies and to use as additional capital for selling fish

loans.name: Jose Manuel

texts.pt:
José Manuel Sando M. nasceu no Distrito de Massinga, Província de Inhambane, sul de Moçambique, tem 46 anos de idade, casado e pai de 2 filhos de 14 e 10 anos de idade, ambos frequentam a escola. Frequenta 3º ano do curso de licenciatura em educação física e desporto na Universidade Pedagógica em Maputo. Vive na casa própria com a sua família e não sustenta mais ninguém para alem da sua família.

Saiu de Massinga para Maputo em 1978 afim de dar continuidade com os seus estudos, em 1996 saiu de Maputo para o Distrito de Boane porque havia conseguido o seu terreno para a construção da sua residência. Trabalha no ministério da Educação como docente desde 1988, faz cerca de 4 horas por dia e o resto de tempo aplica no seu negocio que iniciou em 1996 com a ajuda da sua esposa que também desenvolve a mesma actividade. No negocio vende mais cerveja onde consegue um rendimento de cerca de 6.500.00mt por mes e um salário de 6.125.00mt por mes que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa algum na sua conta bancária. 

Já teve empréstimo no banco Procredit, depois de terminar com o pagamento decidiu não continuar, conheceu a Hluvuku através das mobilizações feitas pelos oficiais de crédito naquela parcela. Este é o seu 2º empréstimo no valor de 15.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar produtos (cerveja, refrescos, cigarros e outros) para aumentar a quantidade da sua mercadoria no seu estabelecimento. O empréstimo anterior foi de 10.000.00mt para a mesma actividade.
 
 Futuramente gostaria de solicitar mais empréstimos para iniciar a actividade de criação de frangos de corte e melhorar a sua residência.
texts.en:
José Manuel Sando M. was born in the District of Massinga, Province of Inhambane, south of Mozambique. He's 46 years old. He's a husband and father of 2 children ages, 14 and 10, both going to school. He’s currently attending his 3rd year studying for a BA in Physical Education at the Universidade Pedagógica in Maputo. He lives in his own house with his family and doesn’t support anybody else except for them. He left Massinga for Maputo in 1978 to continue his education, but in 1996 he moved to the District of Boane because he bought land to build his home. He works for the Ministry of Education as a teacher since 1988. He works around 4 hours a day and he devotes the rest of time to his business, which he opened in 1996 with her wife, who also works performing the same activity. They sell corn beer, making around 6.500.00mt a month. He also earn a salary of 6.125.00mt a month, which he uses to cover household expenses. He even saves some money to put on his bank account. He received a loan from the Procredit bank, but he decided to leave after the finished paying it. He met Hluvuku through several campaigns carried out by loan official in his area. This is his 2nd loan for an amount of 15.000.00mt which he will use to buy products such as beer, soft drinks, cigarettes and others, to increase his stock. His previous loan was for 10.000.00mt for this same activity. (1 dollar = 28.51MT) In the future, he would like to request for more loan to begin with a new activity: breeding farmyard chicken to use that money for home improvements.

Translated from Portuguese by Jimena Lopez, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase items such as beer, soft drinks and others

loans.name: Léontine

texts.fr: K. Léontine est née en 1965 et réside depuis 22 ans au quartier Fiégnon à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à CODJO Saturnin un revendeur, Léontine est mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. Léontine vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Léontine n’a fait que l’école primaire. Depuis près de 15 ans, Léontine vend des divers (bols en séries, sacs de riz, piles, savons, allumettes, conserves, etc.) et aussi des filets de pêche à son domicile. Léontine s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et aussi au Ghana, Etat voisin du Bénin. Léontine avait obtenu deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés. Léontine désire renforcer son capital et augmenter le stock de ses produits afin de mieux répondre à la demande de ses clients. C’est pourquoi, Léontine sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Leontine K. was born in 1965 and for the last 22 years has resided in the Fiegnon neighborhood of Cottonou, the economic capital of Benin. Leontine is married to Saturnin Codjo a retail salesman and is the mother of four school-aged children. Léontine lives with her children and husband. Togther, the couple supports the needs of their family. Léontine has only a primary school education. For the past 15 years has sold various products ( sets of bowls, batteries, sacks of rice, soap, matches, preserves, etc.) and also fillets of fish, from her home. Leontine has made two loans through ALIDe which she has duly repaid. Leontine would like to strengthen her working capital and increase her stock of products to better meet the needs of her clients. For this reason, she is requesting a third loan from ALIDe.

Translated from French by David Gibbons, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various products for resale: sacks of rice, soaps, preserves and fillets of fish.

loans.name: Sabougnouma Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq membres du groupe Sabougnouma sont essentiellement des femmes mariées  qui ont  une moyenne d’âge de 43 ans, 4 enfants et qui  vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Hamdallaye un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso, 3ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur cinquième  prêt solidaire. Les prêts antérieurs ont été tous bien remboursés. 
Elles font la vente de chaussures, de pomme de terre, de condiments alimentaires, de l’essence etc  et de la restauration. 
Avec leur nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, 20 douzaines de chaussures, 5 sacs de 100kg de pomme de terre, 6 paquets de condiments alimentaires, 250 litres d’essence et  2 sacs de 100kg de riz + 4 paquets 5 paquets de condiments pour faire la restauration. 
Elles s’approvisionnent au marché de Sikasso ville et dans les villages avoisinants.
Elles vendent au marché de Médine et de Hamdallaye, de façon ambulante  dans les quartiers et à domicile, au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 25.250FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
Elles ambitionnent demander plus de capitaux pour aménager leur point de vente et mieux satisfaire leurs clientèles.
texts.en:
The five members of the group Sabougnouma are essentially married women who average 43 years of age and four children each. They live for the most part in polygamous families in Hamdallaye, a district of the city of Sikasso, 3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali.  These women are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to meet the needs of their customers and are now on their fifth solidarity loan.  The previous loans have all been repaid.  The group members sells shoes, potatoes, condiments, gasoline, etc., and they work in food service.
