With their new loan, they intend to buy 20 dozen shoes, five 100-kg sacks of potatoes, six packets of condiments, 250 liters of gasoline, and two 100-kg sacks of rice, plus four or five packets of condiments for food catering.  Supplies are gotten at the Sikasso City market and in the neighboring villages.  Sales are made at the Médine market, at the Hamdallaye market, from door to door in the districts, and at home.  Cash or credit is accepted from customers composed of men and women. The group members each envision realizing an average monthly profit of 25,250 francs CFA.  Part of the profits will be put toward savings and the needs of the family.  The other part will be invested into the businesses.  Their ambition is to ask for more capital to fix up their sales outlet and to satisfy their customers further.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying various goods

loans.name: Albertina Pedro

texts.pt:
Albertina Pedro G. nasceu na Província de Sofala, centro de Moçambique, tem 54 anos de idade, viúva e mãe de 8 filhos de 28 a 18 anos de idade, destes tem dois pares de gémeos de 3 de 26 anos e 2 de 24 anos de idade, os mais novos frequentam a escola. Fez somente 1ª classe não continuou porque os pais não deixaram. Vive na casa própria com seus filhos e ainda ajuda a irmã e 4 sobrinhos para o sustento da família. 

Saiu de Sofala para Maputo no Distrito de Boane com o seu falecido marido ainda militar, fixaram sua residência em Boane e mais tarde o marido perdeu a vida. Iniciou uma actividade agrícola para poder sustentar os filhos, esta actividade aprendeu com os pais ainda em sofala. Recebe a pensão do falecido marido no valor de 4.000.00mt e 1.500.00mt provenientes da ajuda prestada pelos filhos que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa algum na sua conta bancária e no Xitique (sistema tradicional de poupança rotativa) mensal. 

Nunca teve empréstimos em bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de vizinhas que também são clientes desta instituição. Este é o seu 4º empréstimo no valor de 15.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (barrotes, chapas, cimento, areia e janelas) para dar continuidade com a construção da sua residência. Os empréstimos anteriores foram de 8.500.00mt, 13.000mt e 13.000.00mt todos para a mesma actividade.
 
 Futuramente gostaria de solicitar mais empréstimos para dar continuidade com a construção da sua residência e oferecer melhores condições de habitabilidade a sua família.
texts.en:
Albertina Pedro G. was born in Sofala Province in central Mozambique. She is 54 years old, a widow, and the mother of 8 children who range in age from 28 to 18 years old. Of these, she has two sets of twins: one pair that is 26 years old and one pair that is 24 years old. The youngest go to school. She only went to school through the 1st grade because her parents wouldn't let her continue. She lives in her own home with her children and even helps her sister and 4 nieces and nephews with family support. She left Sofala for Maputo, Boane District with her now deceased husband when he was still a soldier. They made their home in Boane and later, her husband lost his life. She began agricultural work in order to support her children. She learned about this work with her parents when she was still in Sofala. She receives the pension of her deceased husband, which has a value of 4,000 MZN. 1,500 of the aid given for her children goes toward household expenses. She even manages to save some monthly in her bank account and in Xiqitue (a traditional rotating savings system). She never has had loans through banks. She found out about Hluvuku through neighbors who are also clients of this institution. This is her 4th loan, which has a value of 15,000 MZN. With it, she plans to buy construction materials (beams, panes, cement, sand, and windows) in order to continue with the construction of her house. The previous loans had values of 8,500 MZN, 13,000 MZN, and 13,000 MZN. All were for the same purpose. In the future, she would like to ask for more loans in order to continue with the construction of her home and to provide better living conditions for her family.

Translated from Portuguese by Erika Korowin, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy construction materials (cement, etc.)

loans.name: Lolo Group

texts.fr:
Les six membres du groupe Lolo sont essentiellement des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 39 ans et ont en moyenne 4 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles monogames au quartier Babemba  un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur cinquième  prêt solidaire. Les prêts précédents ont été tous correctement remboursé. 
Elles font la vente  du   bois de chauffe, de savons, des pagnes wax, des condiments alimentaires etc.   
Avec leur nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, un chargement de camionnette en bois de chauffe, 38 cartons de savons, 15 pièces de pagnes wax  et 6 paquets de condiments alimentaires. 
Elles s’approvisionnent au marché de Sikasso ville et dans les villages avoisinants.
Elles vendent au marché de Médine, de façon ambulante dans les quartiers et à domicile, au comptant, souvent à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 32.500FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The six members of the Lolo group are mainly married women with an average age of 39 and an average of four children each. Most of them live in monogamous families in the Babemba neighborhood of Sikasso town, in the third administrative region of Mali. They collaborate with the micro-finance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, in order to satisfy the needs of their clientèle. They are now on their fifth group loan. All their previous loans have been satisfactorily repaid. These women sell firewood, soap, 'wax pagnes' (colorful West African cloth), food condiments etc. With their new loan, they intend to buy a truckload of firewood, 38 cases of soap, 15 bolts of 'wax pagne' and six packets of food condiments. They stock up at the Sikasso market and in neighboring villages. They sell their goods at Médine market, walking around various neighborhoods, and from home. They accept cash, and often credit, from a clientèle of both men and women. Each of them expects to make an average monthly income of 32,500 FCFA, one part of which will be used for savings and for family needs, and the other part will be invested in their business activities.

Translated from French by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy assorted items

loans.name: No Joke Group

texts.en:
Here are members of the 'No Joke' group from the town of Magburaka in northern Sierra Leone. They are small-scale businesswomen who want a loan in order to expand their businesses in size and quality. In this way, they can make better sales and earn more profit. Consequently, their living conditions will improve to a new level – they can thus better support their school-going children in terms of feeding, clothing, educationally and medically.

On the right in the photo is Aminata K. K., the leader of this group of five. Aminata was born in Matotoka village about eight miles away from Magburaka town. She is age thirty-two, married and has three children. Her husband is a motor mechanic and her children are attending Senior and Junior Secondary Schools.

For over ten years now, Aminata has been selling palm oil (the favorite cooking oil in this country), rice and peppers. With her share of this loan, she will buy gallons of palm oil, bags of rice, and bags of peppers. Aminata can not tell exactly how much of each of these commodities she will buy as prices are not stable.

loans.use: Buy gallons of palm oil, bags of rice, and bags of peppers

loans.name: Adjoua

texts.fr: G. Adjoua est née vers 1961 et vit depuis 20 ans à Fiégnon à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à KOUSSEHOU Germain, un gendarme, Adjoua est mère de six enfants, tous scolarisés. Adjoua vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari à Fiégnon. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Adjoua n’a fait que le cours primaire. Depuis près de 22 ans, Adjoua vend des tenues et aussi des chaussures par le système de distribution, et également à son domicile. Adjoua s’approvisionne à Lomé au Togo, Etat voisin du Bénin, et aussi à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Adjoua est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà obtenu deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. Adjoua voudrait renforcer davantage son activité et plus tard ouvrir une boutique pour y vendre ses produits. C’est la raison pour laquelle Adjoua sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Adjoua G. was born around 1961 and for the past twenty years has lived in the Fiégnon area of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is married to Germain Koussehou, a police officer, with whom she has six school-age children. Adjoua lives with her children and husband in Fiégnon, and the couple both work to cater for their family's needs. Adjoua only attended primary school, and for the past 22 years has sold garments and shoes both through a distribution network and from home. Adjoua sources her goods from Lomé in the Togo, Benin's neighbouring state, and also at Dantokpa, Benin's international market. Adjoua is an existing client of ALIDé, and has already received two ALIDé loans which have been successfully repaid. She would like to bolster her existing business, and later open a shop in order to sell her products on site; this is why she is seeking her third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase garments

loans.name: Bernardo Calab

texts.pt:
Bernardo Calab Botão M. nasceu na cidade da Beira, Província de Sofala, centro de Moçambique, tem 46 anos de idade, casado e pai de 5 filhos de 17, 14, 09, 06 e 01 anos de idade, destes os dois últimos não estudam. Fez 10ª classe não continuou por falta de condições financeiras. Vive na casa dos serviços com sua família e ainda sustenta a sua mãe na Beira enviando dinheiro.

Saiu da Beira para Maputo afim de dar continuidade com os seus estudos em 1982 e acabou fixando sua residência. Trabalha no I.P.U a mais de 21 anos, como motorista e mecânico num horário único das 7:30h as 15:30h. Tem um salário mensal de 2.500.00mt e 2.000.00mt através de prestação de serviços aos terceiros. Este aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa algum na sua conta bancária. 

Nunca teve empréstimos em bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de colegas de serviço que também são clientes desta instituição. Este é o seu 4º empréstimo no valor de 15.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (barrotes, chapas, cimento, ferro, areia e janelas) para dar continuidade com a construção da sua residência. Os empréstimos anteriores foram de 6.000.00mt, 10.000.00mt e 13.000.00mt todos para a mesma actividade.
 
 Futuramente gostaria de solicitar mais empréstimos para dar continuidade com a construção da sua residência, sair da casa dos serviços e oferecer melhores condições de habitabilidade a sua família.
texts.en:
Bernardo Calab Botão M. was born in the city of Beira, Sofala Province, in central Mozambique. He is 46 years old, married, and the father of 5 children who are 17, 14, 9, 6, and 1 years old. The youngest two children don't go to school. He only studied through 10th grade due to lack of funds. He lives in the service worker houses with his family and even supports his mother in Beira by sending money. He left Beira for Maputo in order to continue with his studies in 1982 and ended up making a home there. He has worked for the I.P.U. (Inter-Parliamentary Union) for more than 21 years as a driver and mechanic. His working schedule is from 7:30am to 3:30pm. He receives a monthly salary of 2,500 MZN and receives 2,000 MZN for services for third parties. He uses this for household expenses and even saves some in his bank account. He has never had loans through banks. He found out about Hluvuku through service colleagues who are also clients of this institution. This is his 4th loan, which has a value of 15,000 MZN. He plans to use this to buy construction materials (beams, panes, cement, steel, sand, and windows) in order to continue to build his home. The previous loans were for 6,000 MZN, 10,000 MZN, and 13,000 MZN, all for the same purpose. In the future, he would like to ask for more loans in order to continue to build his home, move out of the service worker houses, and provide better living conditions for his family.

Translated from Portuguese by Erika Korowin, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy construction materials (cement, steel, etc.)

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq membres du groupe Benkadi de l’association Yankadi sont essentiellement des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 47ans, 4enfants et  vivant la plupart dans des familles polygames  à Médine, un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur sixième  prêt de groupe. Tous les prêts passés se sont bien dénoués. 
Elles font la vente  du  bois de chauffe, des concentrées de tomates, des tomates fraîches,  des pagnes wax, real, des  condiments alimentaires etc.   
Avec leur nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, un chargement de camionnette en bois de chauffe, une dizaine de paniers de tomates, 15 pièces de pagnes wax – real et 5 paquets de divers condiments alimentaires. 
Elles s’approvisionnent au marché de Sikasso ville et dans les villages avoisinants.
Elles vendent au marché de Médine, de façon ambulante  et à domicile, au comptant et souvent à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 30.500FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera investie dans les  activités.
texts.en:
The five members of the Benkadi group of the Yankadi association are essentially married women, with in average 4 children and 47 years of age. Most of them live in polygamous families in Médine, a city area of Sikasso, the third administrative region of Mali. They collaborate with the microfinance institution Yiriwaso in order to be able satisfy their customers' demand. This is their sixth group loan and they fully repaid the previous ones. They sell wood for heating, concentrated tomato paste, fresh tomatoes, wax- and real-type pagnes (west African traditional clothes), condiments, etc. With this new loan they plan to buy a van load of wood for heating, a dozen baskets of tomatoes, 15 pieces of wax and real pagnes and 5 boxes of different condiments. They buy their supplies at the market of the city of Sikasso and in other neighbor villages. They sell to men and women at the market place in Médine, on the streets and door-to-door, for cash and often for credit. They plan to achieve an average individual monthly revenue of 30.500FCFA, and they will use a part for the family needs and the rest will be invested in their business.

Translated from French by MONICA URBAN, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of different items to sell.

loans.name: Anabel

texts.en: Anabel P. is from the village of Olingan. She is 29 years old, is married, and has four school-aged children. Anabel owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP average per month. In 2006, Anabel joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from PMPC. Anabel is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to invest in a new line of business such as a sari-sari (variety) store. This loan will be her 8th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family and to pay for her children's education. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in a new business such as a sari-sari store

loans.name: Benice

texts.en: Benice sells kerosene at retail prices to her customers. She is 33 years-old and married with a seven year-old child. Her husband is a policeman. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She is an honest and faithful Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) client. Kiva partner LAPO is committed to improving lives in Africa, particularly in Nigeria. She is requesting a loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more kerosene to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase kerosene.

loans.name: Elias Sebastiao

texts.pt:
Elias Sebastião S. nasceu no Distrito de Boane, Província de Maputo, sul de Moçambique, tem 29 anos de idade, casado e pai de 2 filhos de 6 e 9 anos de idade, todos vão a escola. Não estudou porque os pais na altura não o deixaram estudar porque davam prioridade o trabalho da machamba e pastagem de gado bovino. Vive na casa dos serviços com sua família e ainda sustenta a sua mãe e um sobrinho que vivem com ele.

Nuca saiu de Boane apenas saiu da casa dos pais para construir sua própria residência. Trabalha juntos com a sua esposa na Banalandia uma empresa de produção e venda de Banana no Distrito de Boane. Faz cerca de 8 horas por dia e tem um salário mensal de 1.630.00mt que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa algum através de Xitique (sistema tradicional de poupança rotativa)

Nunca teve empréstimos em bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de colegas de serviço que também são clientes desta instituição. Este é o seu 2º empréstimo no valor de 10.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (barrotes, chapas, cimento, ferro, areia e janelas) para dar continuidade com a construção da sua residência. O empréstimo anterior foi de 6.600.00mt, para a mesma actividade.
 
 Futuramente gostaria de solicitar mais empréstimos para dar continuidade com a construção da sua residência, e oferecer melhores condições de habitabilidade a sua família.
texts.en:
Elias Sebastião S. was born in Boane District, Maputo Province, in southern Mozambique. He is 29 years old, married, and is the father of 2 children who are 6 and 9 years old. They both go to school. He did not go to school because his parents at that time didn't let him study. This was because they gave priority to working on the machamba (a small agricultural field) and in the cattle pasture. He lives in the service worker houses with his family and even supports his mother and a nephew, who both live with him. He has never left Boane, only leaving his parents' house to build his own home. He works together with his wife in Banalandia at a banana production and sales business in Boane District. He works about 8 hours each day and receives a monthly salary of 1,630 MZN that he uses for household expenses. He even saves some through Xitique (a traditional rotating savings system). He has never had loans through banks. He found out about Hluvuku through service colleagues who are also clients of this institution. This is his 2nd loan, which has a value of 10,000 MZN. With it, he plans to buy construction materials (beams, panes, cement, steel, sand, and windows) in order to continue with the construction of his house. The previous loan was for 6,600 MZN, for the same purpose. In the future, he would like to ask for more loans in order to continue to build his house and provide better living conditions for his family.

Translated from Portuguese by Erika Korowin, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy construction materials (cement, a door, etc.)

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre  membres du groupe Benkadi  de l’association Dièlegnan sont essentiellement des femmes mariées qui ont en moyenne  47ans,  7 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des familles polygames à Ouayerma II, un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur deuxième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leurs clientèles. 
Le prêt précédent fut correctement remboursé, sans aucune difficulté. 
Elles font la vente  de tapis, de vêtements  pour enfants, du bois de chauffe, des produits de beauté, des produits pharmaceutiques naturels etc. .  
Avec leur nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, un chargement de camionnette en bois de chauffe, 6 tapis de format  moyen et 4 douzaines de vêtements pour enfants. Elles s’approvisionnent au marché de Sikasso ville et dans les villages avoisinants.
Elles vendent au marhé de Ouayerma II de façon fixe,  de façon ambulante dans la ville et à domicile, au comptant et quelques fois à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 20.500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
Elles ambitionne demander plus de capitaux pour aménager leur point de vente et mieux satisfaire leurs clientèles.
texts.en:
The four members of the Benkadi group, part of the Dièlegnan association, are primarily married women. They are of an average age of 47 and have an average of 7 children. They generally live in polygamous families in Ouayerma II, one of the districts of Sikasso, the third largest administrative region in Mali. This is the second project that they have undertaken with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance organisation in order to meet their customers' needs; their first loan was repaid successfully. They sell rugs, children's clothes, firewood, beauty products, natural pharmaceutical products, etc. With their new loan they intend to buy a cartload of firewood, 6 mid-sized rugs and 4 dozen lots of children's clothes. They source their products from the Sikasso town market and neighbouring villages. They sell their goods from market stalls at Ouayerma II and through mobile sales in town and at home. Sales are cash- and sometimes credit-based, and their customer base is made up of both men and women. The women envisage generating an average monthly profit of 20,500 FCFA; some of this would be saved or spent on family needs, and the rest would be reinvested in the business. They aim to ask for more funds in order to equip their store and to satisfy the demands of their customers.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase various items

loans.name: Carlos Ernesto

texts.pt:
Carlos Ernesto N. nasceu na Cidade de Maputo, Província do Mesmo nome, sul de Moçambique, tem 36 anos de idade, casado e pai de 4 filhos de 6, 7, 9 e 11 anos de idade, todos vão a escola. Fez somente 3ª classe não continuou porque perdeu os pais e não tinha ninguém que podia sustentar os seus estudos. Vive na casa dos serviços com sua família e ainda sustenta seus irmãos enviando dinheiro para o pagamento de energia e água.

Saiu de Maputo para Boane para fixar uma nova residência com a sua família depois de ter conseguido um novo talhão. Trabalha como motorista na ferragem raia em Boane a mais de 8 anos e faz em media cerca de 10 horas por dia, e tem um salário mensal de 6.799.00mt que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa algum na sua conta bancária.

Nunca teve empréstimos em bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de colegas de serviço que também são clientes desta instituição. Este é o seu 2º empréstimo no valor de 8.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (barrotes, chapas, cimento, ferro e areia) para dar continuidade com a construção da sua residência. O empréstimo anterior foi de 5.500.00mt, para a mesma actividade.
 
 Futuramente gostaria de solicitar mais empréstimos para dar continuidade com a construção da sua residência e iniciar uma actividade comercial.
texts.en:
Carlos Ernesto N. was born in the city of Maputo, Maputo Province, in southern Mozambique. He is 36 years old, married, and the father of 4 children who are 6, 7, 9, and 11 years old. All go to school. He only studied through the 3rd grade because his parents died and he didn't have anybody who could support his studies. He lives in the service workers houses with his family and even supports his brothers and sisters by sending money for the power and water bills. He left Maputo for Boane in order to set up a new home with his family after he found a new job. He has worked as a driver in the outlying ironworks sector for more than 10 years and works on average around 10 hours each day. He receives a monthly salary of 6,799 MZN that he uses for household expenses. He even saves some in his bank account. He has never had loans through banks. He found out about Hluvuku through service colleagues who are also clients of this institution. This is his 2nd loan, which has a value of 8,000 MZN. He plans to use it to buy construction materials (beams, panes, cement, steel, and sand) in order to continue with the construction of his house. The previous loan was for 5,500 MZN, for the same purpose. In the future he would like to ask for more loans to continue to build his house and to start a commercial business.

Translated from Portuguese by Erika Korowin, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy construction materials (cement, steel, etc.)

loans.name: Wass Na Good Dae Sade Group

texts.en:
This group of entrepreneurs named their group 'Wasse Na God Dae Sade'. They are small-scale businesswomen in the town of Magburaka in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of SLL 500,000 each to improve their businesses.

Kadiatu C. on the left in the photo is the leader of this group of four. Thirty-seven years old, Kadiatu was born in Mashikore, in northern Sierra Leone. She is married with six children. Her husband is a professional worker and five of her children are attending school.

Kadiatu sells market food – oil, 'margi' (used to give sauce a sweet taste), onions, salt, pepper, sugar, etc. She has been a businesswoman for many years. With her share of this loan, she will buy one bag of onions, one bag of sugar, and one bag of salt.

loans.use: Buy one bag of onions, one bag of sugar, and one bag of salt

loans.name: Vitesse Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Vitesse sont essentiellement des femmes mariées  ayant  une moyenne d’âge de 43 ans, 5 enfants et  vivant la plupart dans des familles polygames à Ouayerma II un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. 
Elles sont à leur cinquième prêt solidaire et tous les précédents se sont bien dénoués. 
Elles font la vente  du bois de chauffe, des fruits et légumes, des pommades et la fabrication  de boissons  non alcoolisées telles le jus de gingembre.
Avec leur nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, un chargement de camionnette en bois de chauffe, 4 paniers d’oranges, 3 régimes de bananes, 2 sacs d’ananas, 5 colis de pommades et 1 sac de 50kg de sucre +3 sacs de 100kg du gousse de gingembre (pour la préparation du jus de gingembre). 
Elles s’approvisionnent au marché de Sikasso ville et dans les villages avoisinants.
Elles vendent au grand marché de Sikasso, de façon ambulante dans les quartiers  et à domicile, au comptant, souvent à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 20.500FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The members of the Vitesse group are essentially married women who are on average 43 years old with an average of five children and mostly living in polygamous families in Ouyerma II, one of the districts of the town of Sikasso in the 3rd administrative region of Mali. They work together with the microfinance company, Soro Yiriwaso, in order to satisfy the demand of their customers. They are on their fifth group loan and all the previous loans have been repaid without any problem. They sell firewood, fruit and vegetables and creams and also make non-alcoholic drinks such as ginger juice. With their new loan they are planning to buy a truck load of firewood, four baskets of oranges, three stems of bananas, two bags of pineapple, five parcels of creams, one 50kg bag of sugar and three 100kg bags of root ginger (for the preparation of the ginger juice). They get their supplies at the market in Sikasso and in the neighbouring villages. They sell at the large market in Sikasso, moving around the various districts and from door to door, for cash and also on credit to a customer base made up of men and women. They are counting on making an average monthly profit of 20,500FCFA each, of which part will be used for savings and the rest invested in their business.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of various products

loans.name: Catelina Boaze

texts.pt:
Catelina Boaze N. nasceu no Distrito de Manjacaze, Província de Gaza, sul de Moçambique, tem 45 anos de idade, viúva e mãe de 3 filhos de 22, 16 e 14 anos de idade, todos vão a escola. Fez somente 5ª classe não continuou porque não tinha condições financeiras por parte dos pais. Vive na casa própria com sua família e ainda sustenta sua irmã que vive com ela

Saiu de Manjacaze para Boane com seus pais quando ela tinha apenas 13 anos, a procura de melhores condições de vida. Trabalha no restaurante Roma como auxiliar de limpezas a mais de 1 ano. Tem um negocio próprio em sua casa que desenvolve com a ajuda dos filhos a mais de 15 anos, consegue um rendimento de cerca de 4.000.00mt por mes e um salário de 2.500.00mt por mes que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa algum na sua conta bancária.

Nunca teve empréstimos em bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de colegas de serviço que também são clientes desta instituição. Este é o seu 2º empréstimo no valor de 8.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (cimento, ferro e areia) para dar continuidade com a construção da sua residência. O empréstimo anterior foi de 5.000.00mt, para a mesma actividade.
 
 Futuramente gostaria de solicitar mais empréstimos para dar continuidade com a construção da sua residência e iniciar uma actividade comercial.
texts.en:
Catelina Boaze N. was born in Manjacaze District, Gaza Province, in southern Mozambique. She is 45 years old, a widow, and the mother of 3 children who are 22, 16, and 14 years old. All go to school. She only studied through the 5th grade; she didn't continue because of her parents' financial situation. She lives in her own house with her family and even supports her sister who lives with her. She left Manjacaze for Boane with her parents when she was only 13 years old in order to seek out better living conditions. She has worked in the Roma restaurant as a cleaning assistant for more than 1 year. She has had her own business in her home that she runs with the help of her children for more than 15 years. She earns about 4,000 MZN per month from this and receives a salary of 2,500 MZN each month that she uses for household expenses. She even saves some in her bank account. She has never had loans through banks. She found out about Hluvuku through service colleagues who are also clients of this institution. This is her 2nd loan, which has a value of 8,000 MZN. She plans to use it to buy construction material (cement, steel, and sand) in order to continue the construction of her house. The previous loan was for 5,000 MZN, for the same purpose. In the future, she would like to ask for more loans in order to continue the construction of her house and to start a commercial business.

Translated from Portuguese by Erika Korowin, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy construction material (cement, etc.)

loans.name: Edith

texts.en: Edith is a fashion designer and also sells tailoring materials in Agbor, Delta state. She makes lovely Nigerian designs for her customers. This is the high season for sales and she hopes to make more profit. She is an honest and faithful Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) client. Kiva partner LAPO is committed to improving lives in Africa, particularly in Nigeria.  She is 29 years-old and married with three children. Her eldest child is 9 years-old. Her husband is an electrician. She is requesting a loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more tailoring materials to sell. She thanks all her Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring materials.

loans.name: Munh-Ochir

texts.en:
Munh-Ochir J. is 33 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her two children both go to a local kindergarten.

Munh-Ochir has a small business selling a variety of small goods. She rents a small stall at the Narantuul market, the largest outdoor market in Ulaanbaatar, and sells various convenience products, including toilet paper, hygienic tissues, Scotch tape, batteries, etc. She has been a saleswoman at the market since 2000 and has gained significant experience in small retail. She mostly purchases the products from Ereen, China, a border town where many of cheap Chinese products are imported from. She dreams of owning a small nice house for her family. She says that it would be nice to live with her family in a comfortable house, especially during the cold winter.

She requests a loan to purchase more products for this business.

loans.use: To purchase more products to sell

loans.name: Zinsi

texts.fr: V. Zinsi est née en 1974 et vit depuis environs 25 ans à Fiégnon à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à ATYOGBE Joseph, un pêcheur, Zinsi est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Zinsi vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Zinsi n’a pas été à l’école. Pour faire face à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants, Zinsi vend du poisson fumé à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin et aussi à son domicile. Zinsi mène comme activité secondaire, la vente de bois de chauffage. Zinsi a 15 ans d’expérience dans ce métier. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà obtenu trois crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. Zinsi voudrait renforcer son activité et mieux faire face à la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de sa clientèle. C’est la raison pour laquelle Zinsi sollicite un quatrième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
VidjinnagniI Zinsi was born in 1974 and has lived for about 25 years in Fiégnon in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is married to Atyogbe Joseph, who is a fisherman. Zinsi is the mother of three children, all of whom attend school. She lives with her husband and their children. Together, the couple handles their family's needs and expenses. Zinsi did not attend school. In order to handle her needs and those of her children, Zinsi sells smoked fish in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin and also from her house. As a secondary business, Zinsi also sells firewood. Zinsi has had 15 years experience in her business. She is an old client of ALIDé and has already received 3 loans from ALIDé, all of which have been fully repaid. Zinsi wants to strengthen her business and be able to better handle the growing needs of here many clientele. It is for this reason that Zinsi is requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase fresh fish

loans.name: Bayarmaa

texts.en:
Bayarmaa D. is 26 years old and lives with her husband and son. Her son is 6 years old and goes to a local secondary school. Bayarmaa's husband is a herder with a dozen livestock, including sheep, goats and cattle.

Bayarmaa runs a small barber shop in the local town. She rents a small place and cuts locals' hair. She has been in the haircutting business since 2007 and she has already gained some loyal customers who like getting haircuts from her shop. Since her start in 2007, her business capital has increased from 80,000 MNT to 200,000 MNT ($1 USD = 1,450 MNT). This certainly says that her business has been going great.

She requests a loan to purchase necessary equipment to upgrade her business and get ready for the busy season.

loans.use: To purchase necessary equipment for her barber shop

loans.name: Priscilla

texts.en: Priscilla sells clothes. She hopes to own a boutique in the future. She is 31 years-old and married with four children. Her husband is a commercial driver and he also supports the home. She is a hard working and faithful woman.  Priscilla is requesting a loan of NGN 170,000 to purchase more clothes to sell. She is a Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) client. LAPO is committed to improving lives in Africa, particularly in Nigeria. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase clothes.

loans.name: Konsi

texts.fr: K. Konsi est née en 1945 et vit depuis 64 ans à Fiégnon à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à LOUMON Pierre, un pêcheur, Konsi est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. C’est seulement un enfant qui vit encore avec Konsi et son mari. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Konsi n’a fait que l’école primaire. Konsi vend divers produits (pâtes dentifrices, lait corporel, comprimés, etc.) et aussi de l’huile d'arachide et du poisson à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et par le système de distribution. Konsi s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, et au bord de la mer en ce qui concerne l’achat de poissons. Konsi est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant obtenu trois crédits auprès de l’institution, crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. Konsi ne dispose pas suffisamment de moyens financiers, pouvant lui permettre d’agrandir davantage son activité pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle. C’est ce qui l’a conduit à solliciter un quatrième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
K. Konsi was born in 1945 and has lived for the past 64 years in Fiégnon in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Married to Loumon Pierre, a fisherman, Konsi is the mother of 3 children, all of whom attend school. Only one of their children still lives with Konsi and her husband. Together they take care of the needs of their family. Konsi did not attend primary school. Konsi sells a variety of products (toothpaste, moisturizers, compresses etc), peanut oil and fish, from the market of Dantokpa, the international market of Benin and through a distribution system. Konsi supplies herself in Dantokpa and by the sea, where she purchases fish. Konsi is an old client of ALIDé, she has already obtained 3 loans from the micro finance institution, all of which were fully repaid. Konsi does not have sufficient financial means for her business and this loan will enable her to grow her business in order to better satisfy her clientele. It is for this reason that she is requesting a fourth loan with ALIDé.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase toothpaste, moisturizer and crates of peanut oil

loans.name: Fawe, Waterloo Group

texts.en:
These are teachers at the 'Forum for African Woman Educationalist' (FAWE). This is a Junior Secondary School with classes I – III. It was built in September, 2005, by FAWE, a local NGO, for the promotion of education for the less privileged girl child.

This is the second loan these teachers are accessing from SMT/Kiva, a partner of 'Shine on Sierra Leone' in Waterloo. With the help of the previous loan, these staff members were able to complement their monthly salaries – they were able to pay their children’s school fees, invest in their businesses, or solve their immediate financial challenges.

Having repaid their last loan, they are again requesting a loan of SLL 7,300,000 total. With this new loan, some of these borrowers can again pay school fees for their children, invest in their businesses, buy pieces of furniture, or buy house-building material.

Denka M. is the leader of this group of teachers. Denka was born in Kabala town in northern Sierra Leone thirty-nine years ago. He is married and has two children who are attending school. This loan will complement Denka’s salary; he can use it to take greater care of his family and pay school fees for his children.

loans.use: Pay school fees and other school-related charges for his children

loans.name: Louise

texts.fr: M. Louise est née en 1984 et vit depuis 25 ans à Fiégnon à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à DANSOU Jean, un pêcheur, Louise est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Louise a un autre enfant à charge, en plus de ses enfants. Louise vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. C’est principalement le mari de Louise qui assure les charges de la famille. Cependant, Louise utilise les revenus supplémentaires issus de son activité pour venir en aide à son mari. Louise n’a pas été à l’école. Il y a environs 10 ans que Louise vend de « Akpan » (bouillie locale faite à base d’amidon de maïs) à son domicile. A côté de cette activité, Louise vend également du charbon de bois en détail, qu'elle attache dans des sachets. Louise est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, qui a bien remboursé les trois premiers crédits qu’elle a obtenus de ALIDé. Louise sollicite un quatrième crédit auprès de ALIDé, afin d’augmenter le stock de ses produits et de mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
M. Louise was born in 1984 and for the past 25 years she lived in Fiégnon à Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is married to Dansou Jean, a fisherman. Louise is the mother of 3 children, all of whom attend school. Louise also has another child in her care, in addition to her own children. Louise lives with her children and her husband. It is principally Louise's husband who takes care of the needs of the family. Nevertheless, Louise uses the additional income earned from her business in order to help her husband support their family. Louise did not attend school. For about ten years, Louise has sold "Akpan" (a local porridge made from corn starch) from her home. In addition to this business, Louise sells charcoal at retail prices and sells them in bags. Louise is an old customer of ALIDé, and she has fully repaid the 3 loans she has obtained from ALIDé. Louise is requesting a fourth loan from ALIDé, in order to increase her stock of products and better handle the requests of her clientele.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase corn and charcoal

loans.name: Goussi

texts.fr: A. Goussi est née vers 1974 et réside depuis 26 ans à Fiégnon à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Goussi est mariée à KOUASSI Codjo, un pêcheur, et est mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. La famille vit à Fiégnon à Cotonou. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Pour subvenir à ses besoins, Goussi vend divers produits (savons, sardines, lait, sucre, piles, beurre, conserves, etc.) et aussi de la nourriture à son domicile. Goussi s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Il y a deux ans environs que Goussi exerce cette activité. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà obtenu trois crédits auprès de l’institution, crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. Goussi sollicite un quatrième crédit auprès de ALIDé, afin d’élever le niveau de son activité et de constituer ainsi une épargne.
texts.en:
A. Goussi was born in 1974 and for the past 26 years she has lived in Fiégnon in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Goussi is married to Kouassi Codjo, a fisherman, and is the mother of four children, all of whom are attending school. The family lives in Fiégnon in Cotonou. Together, the couple supports the needs of the family. In order to handle the family's needs, Goussi sells a variety of products (soaps, sardines, milk, sugar, batteries, milk, jams etc.) and food; she sells these goods from her home. Goussi supplies herself in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. For about two years, Goussi has had her business. She is an old client of ALIDé and she has obtained three loans from the micro-finance institution, all of each were fully repaid. Goussi is requesting a fourth loan from ALIDé, in order to grow her business and have greater savings.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase a variety of products (boxes of james, sugar, soaps and milk)

loans.name: Philomena

texts.en: Philomena sells kerosene at retail prices to her customers. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She is a LAPO client. The Lift Above Poverty Organization is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. She is married with 6 children and she is 45 years old. Her husband works as a security guard and he also supports the home. She has been in this business for 8 years. She is requesting a loan in the amount of NGN 50,000 to purchase more kerosene to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more kerosene to sell

loans.name: Elisabeth

texts.fr: G. Elisabeth est née en 1949 et réside depuis 40 ans à Fiégnon à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Elisabeth est mariée à AHONTON Raphaël, un agent de sécurité. Le couple a quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. Elisabeth vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Elisabeth n’a pas fréquenté l’école. C’est la raison pour laquelle depuis une vingtaine d’année, Elisabeth vend des poissons fumés, de l’huile d’arachide et divers autres produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Elisabeth mène cette activité, parfois de façon ambulante. Elisabeth s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, et au bord de la mer à Cotonou. Elisabeth a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits à ALIDé, crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. Elisabeth voudrait agrandir son activité, et plus tard la diversifier et ouvrir ensuite une boutique pour y vendre ses produits. C’est ce qui amène Elisabeth à solliciter un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
G. Elisabeth was born in 1949 and for the past 40 years, she has lived in Fiégnon in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Elisabeth is married to Ahonton Raphaël, a security guard. The couple has four children, all of whom are attending school. Elisabeth lives with her children and her husband. Together, the couple cares for the needs of the family. Elisabeth did not attend school. For this reason, for about the past twenty years, Elisabeth has been selling smoked fish, peanut oil and various other products in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. Elisabeth manages her business and usually sells her wares as she walks about town. Elisabeth supplies herself in Dantokpa and by the sea on Cotonou. Elisabeth has already benefitted from two loans with ALIDé, both of which she fully repaid. Elisabeth would like to grow her business, to diversify it and to open a shop where she can sell her products. It is for this reason that Elisabeth is requesting a third loan with ALIDé.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase fresh fish and crates of peanut oil.

loans.name: Bwavumpologoma Men And Women Group, Kayunga

texts.en:
N. Dumba is the leader of her group in Kayunga. She is a strong business lady with a business of selling produce. She buys the produce from the farmers in the villages, who have barely any means to transport their produce to the market. She also grows some of the produce herself, though what she has is never enough compared to what she needs for a single sale.

Whenever N. has a loan, even after having accumulated savings, she is able to buy in bulk, and at times buys a plantation from which she gets the food slowly, depending on her market, since the foods she deals in are all perishable. She has been able to buy herself a motorcycle, and she has cows and goats at home. Dumba needs a loan to help buy more produce for resale.

loans.use: To buy more produce for resale

loans.name: Kaï

texts.fr: N. Kaï est née en 1977 et vit depuis 15 ans à Fiégnon à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Kaï est mariée à AMOUSSOU Koffi, un pêcheur. Le couple a trois enfants en charge, dont deux sont leurs propres enfants. Tous les enfants sont scolarisés et vivent ensemble avec leurs parents. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Kaï n’a pas été à l’école. Pour faire face à ses besoins, Kaï vend divers produits de toilette (savons, lait corporel, crème, eau de toilette, parfums, défrisants, etc.) et aussi des mèches à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin et au marché de Fiégnon à Cotonou. C’est à Dantokpa que Kaï s’approvisionne. Kaï a trois ans d’expérience dans cette activité, et est à son troisième crédit à ALIDé. Kaï a bien remboursé les deux crédits qu’elle avait obtenus de ALIDé. En vue de renforcer son capital, et mieux satisfaire ses clients, Kaï sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Kaï ambitionne vendre plus tard ses produits en gros.
texts.en:
N. Kaï was born in 1977 and for the past 15 years she has lived in Fiégnon in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Kaï is married to Amoussou Koffi, a fisherman. The couple cares for 3 children, two of whom are their own children. All of the children attend school and live together with their parents. Together the couple takes care of the needs of the family. Kaï did not attend school. In order to take care of the family's needs, Kaï sells a variety of cosmetic products (soaps, moisturizer, lotions, eau de toilette, perfumes, hair straighteners, etc.) and also hair weaves in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin and the market of Fiégnon in Cotonou. Kaï supplies herself in Dantokpa. Kaï has had three years of experience in this business and this is her third loan with ALIDé. Kaï has fully repaid her previous two loans from ALIDé. In order to grow her funds and better satisfy the needs of her clientele, Kaï is requesting a third loan from ALIDé. Kaï's ambition is to sell products at wholesale.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase cartons of cosmetics products

loans.name: Uktam

texts.en:
K. Uktam is a 40-year-old married man who lives with his 4 children. He has been running a business of raising and selling cattle. He has 12 years of experience in this field. Since cattle raising and selling is a profitable business, Uktam has become a very successful businessman in a very short period. He works very hard and spends all his time with the cattle, cleaning, feeding and pasturing them.

Now Uktam wants to expand his business and buy more cattle. Therefore Uktam applied for a loan of $3000 USD. He thanks all lenders for their support. With your help, Uktam can get ahead.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture, and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase more cattle

loans.name: Henry Gitau

texts.en:
Henry Gitau is 34 years old and married to Salome Waithera. They have a son called Lawrence K.. Henry was introduced to Kadet by a former neighbour who is a Kadet client who had borrowed a loan previously with another microfinance institution.

Henry runs a series of businesses, all located in Kisumu Ndogo-Malindi. They include a barbershop, a tailoring shop, a stall where he has placed a pool table, and a boda boda (bicycle) taxi from which he gets a monthly profit of Kshs 7,000. He has been operating all these for nine years. With this loan, he plans to add a pool table to the one he already has, and add materials for his tailoring business. With the extra earnings/profits, he will build a place where all his businesses can be located.

He desires to be a prominent business entrepreneur in Malindi.

loans.use: To purchase a pool table (Kshs 45000) and tailoring materials (Kshs 15000)

loans.name: Angèle

texts.fr: A. M. Angèle est née le 04 Janvier 1970 et vit depuis 25 ans à Fiégnon à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à ANANI Couassi, un pêcheur, Angèle est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Angèle vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Angèle n’a fait que le cours primaire. Depuis près de 20 ans, Angèle vend des ustensiles de cuisine en plastique, et aussi des vivres au marché de Fiégnon et à son domicile. Angèle s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà bénéficié de trois crédits à ALIDé, crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. Angèle sollicite un quatrième crédit auprès de ALIDé, afin d’accroître son activité et de mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
A. M. Angèle was born January 4th, 1970 and for the past 25 years has lived in Fiégnon in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is married to Anani Couassi, a fisherman. Angèle is the mother of three children, all of whom are attending school. Angèle lives with her children and her husband. Together the couple supports the needs of the family. Angèle did not attend school. For the past 20 years, Angèle has sold plastic cooking utensils and fresh foods in the market of Fiégnon and from her home. Angèle supplies herself from Dantokpa, the international market in Benin. She is an old client of ALIDé, and she has benefitted from three previous loans from ALIDé, all of the previous loans have been fully repaid. Angèle is requesting a fourth loan from ALIDé, in order to grow her business and be able to better respond to the needs of her clientele.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase plastic cooking utensils

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en: Lilian sells bags of cement at wholesale and retail prices. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She is 29 years old and is married with 2 children. Her eldest child is 2 years old. She has been in this business for 8 years. She is a faithful and hard working woman. She hopes to be a major cement distributor in the future. She hopes for a loan in the amount of NGN 170,000 to purchase more bags of cement to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of cements to sell

loans.name: Ilhomjon

texts.en:
Ilhomjon lives in Djabbar Rasulov, Tajikistan. He is 43 years old and married with 4 children. Ilhomjon is the sole provider for his family and earns his living by raising livestock and selling them at the local market. Every year he purchases young calves from local villagers, raises them over an 8-9 month period, and then sells the adult cows and bulls to local butchers.

Today Ilhomjon is thinking about expanding his business, as his current earnings are not enough to provide for his family. He plans to purchase young cattle and feed for them. That’s why he is requesting a loan of $1500 USD. Extend your solidarity to Ilhomjon so that he can move forth successfully and accomplish all his goals.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing small cattle and feed for them

loans.name: Nicholas Mutisya

texts.en:
Nicholas is 33 years old and married to Angela Nduku. They have two boys: Dennis and Antony. He was introduced to Kadet by an existing client (Agnes), who happens to have been nominated as the best client in the Kadet Malindi branch.

Nicholas's business is located in Malindi town and deals with selling electronics and household items (commonly known as mali mali) at wholesale prices. He supplies these to small retail shops within Malindi town.

Nicholas has been in this business for the last five years and gets a monthly profit of Kshs 25,000. With this loan, he plans to add stock, put up new shelves, and also introduce cosmetic products in his shop.

A very ambitious man, Nicholas plans to secure permanent premises for his business with the extra earnings from his business loan.

loans.use: Kshs 20000 for buying watches, radios, and sunglasses; Kshs 10000 to put up shelves in the premise; Kshs 10000 to introduce cosmetic products

loans.name: Eugénie

texts.fr: M. Eugénie est née en 1974 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Eugénie réside à Fiégnon à Cotonou, depuis une vingtaine d’année. Mariée à ACHAHOUN Joseph un pêcheur, Eugénie est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés. Seulement un enfant reste encore à sa charge. Eugénie vit ensemble avec son enfant et son mari. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Eugénie n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Depuis près de 15 ans, Eugénie mène comme activité, la vente de poissons fumés devant sa maison. C’est au bord de la mer que Eugénie s’approvisionne. Eugénie a obtenu deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, et les a bien remboursés. Eugénie sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé, en vue de renforcer son activité et de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
M. Eugénie was born in 1974 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Eugénie has lived in Fiégnon in Cotonou, for the past 20 years. She is married to Achahoun Joseph, a fisherman; Eugénie is the mother of two children, both of whom attend school. Only one of the children is still in her care. Eugénie lives with her child and her husband. Together the couple supports the needs of the family. Eugénie did not attend much school. For the past 15 years, Eugénie has managed her business, selling smoked fish from her house. Eugénie supplies herself from the seaside. Eugénie has obtained two loans from ALIDé, and both have been fully repaid. Eugénie is requesting a third loan from ALIDé, in order to improve her business and better satisfy the needs of her clientele.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase fresh fish

loans.name: Lurenzo Govie Memorial Secondary School, Waterloo Group

texts.en:
These are teachers at the Lerenzo Govie Memorial Secondary School. This school was named after its founder, Lerenzo Govie, in 1974. It is a junior secondary school with junior secondary school classes I – III (JSS I-III).

This group of teachers has come to SMT, a partner of 'Shine on Sierra Leone' in Waterloo to seek a loan in order to supplement their monthly salaries. With the help this loan, these teachers can meet their immediate financial challenges and at the end of each month would repay the loan out of their salaries.

Lucian W. K. (first row, third from left) is the bursar at the school and leader of this group of teachers. Forty years old, Lucian was born in Hastings, near Freetown. She is married to a teacher and they have three children. Lucian’s children are attending school and with her share of the loan, she will pay school fees and other school-related charges for her children.

loans.use: Pay school fees and other school-related charges for her children

loans.name: Rustam

texts.en:
N. Rustam is a 43-year-old cattleman who is married with three children. Owing to his father, who was a farmer, Rustam has been associated with this business since he was young. He purchases the cattle in the local market and then he breeds and sells them. The cattle are kept in the house and it takes a lot of effort to care for them. Every day, Rustam gets up early in the morning in order to feed his animals. And all day, until late at night, he is busy looking after the cattle. Rustam says that he works with only one aim in mind: to provide his children with a proper education.

Now, Rustam would like to expand his business and purchase three cows. For this purpose, he has applied for 5000 Somoni and with your help he hopes to reach his aim.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing cattle to expand the business.

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en:
Vivian is forty-two years old. She is a wife and the mother of three children. She trades in ‘batik tie and dye’. Batik tie and dye is a locally made fabric designed with dye. It is mostly patronized by traditional women for various fabric designs for different occasions.

Vivian wants to use the loan to purchase batik tie and die in bulk, and also include the sale of lace cloth. Vivian is anticipating higher profit in the coming Christmas season and she hopes to use part of her profit to provide her children with a quality education.

loans.use: To purchase stock in bulk.

loans.name: Akouavi

texts.fr: F. Akouavi est née en 1957 et vit depuis 30 ans à Fiégnon à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à MENSAH François, un pêcheur, Akouavi est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Akouavi vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Akouavi n’a jamais été à l’école. Il y a environs 40 ans que Akouavi vend des poissons fumés et aussi des condiments de sauce à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Akouavi s’approvisionne au bord de la mer. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant obtenu déjà trois crédits à ALIDé, et qui ont été bien remboursés. Akouavi désire élever le niveau de son activité et répondre efficacement à la demande de sa clientèle. C’est la raison pour laquelle Akouavi sollicite un quatrième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
F. Akouavi was born in 1957 and for the past 30 years she has lived in Fiégnon in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is married to Mensah François, a fisherman; Akouavi is married to 3 children, all of whom are attending school. Akouavi lives with her husband and their children. Together the couple cares for the needs of the family. Akouavi never attended school. For about 40 years, Akouavi has sold smoked fish and also condiments/ sauces in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. Akouavi supplies herself at the seaside. Akouavi is an old client of ALIDé and has obtained 3 loans from the micro-finance institution, all of which have been fully repaid. Akouavi wants to grow her business, in order to respond efficiently to the needs of her clientele. It is for this reason that Akouavi is requesting a fourth loan with ALIDé.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase fresh fish

loans.name: Celina

texts.en: Celina sells groceries at retail prices to her customers.She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She is 50 years old, married, with 6 children. Her husband is a teacher and he also supports the home.She is a LAPO client. The Lift Above Poverty Organization is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. She is requesting a loan of NGN 60,000 to purchase more groceries to sell.  She thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Cicilia

texts.en:
Cicilia M. is currently in the business of selling fresh vegetables in the market. She is requesting a loan to buy other items like rice, beans, groundnuts, posho and maize flour to sell. Cicilia is 27 years old and single. She has 2 children and her children do not go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to send her children to school.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services. These programs are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy rice, beans, groundnuts, posho and maize flour to sell

loans.name: Nkokonjeru Model Group, Lugazi

texts.en:
Musa L. is the leader of his lending group in Lugazi. He is a hardworking and devoted man with a boda boda business, a motorcycle transport system that he has been running for a long time. 

He is grateful for his loans because he has been able to save from his daily income and open a retail shop for his wife to manage from their home. At the start of his loans, six years ago, he had no motorcycle of his own but now the one he has is his and he plans to have a fleet of motorcycles so that he can earn more. 

Musa is a father of three children who are in primary school. He also takes care of his other siblings. Musa needs a loan to be able to restock his wife’s retail shop with more goods.

loans.use: Restocking his retail shop with more products

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is 34 years old. She is divorcee with one child who has just completed senior high school and is waiting to enter the university.  She supports herself and her child through trading. She deals in cosmetics. She sells through hawking, a form of selling whereby the seller moves door to door while carrying her stock on her head. 

Grace says selling cosmetics is very lucrative and therefore she wants to expand her inventory to enable her to make a good income to support her child’s education.

loans.use: To purchase assorted cosmetics

loans.name: Iko

texts.en:
Iko U. is currently in the business of selling rice and beans in the market. She is requesting a loan to stock more bags of rice and beans to sell.  

Iko is 30 years old and married to a police officer. She has three children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a wholesale shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more bags of rice and beans to sell

loans.name: Clemetina

texts.en: Clemetina sells Nigerian cooked foods at retail prices to her customers. She is a LAPO client. The Lift Above Poverty Organization is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. She is 42 years old, married, with 5 children. Her husband is a teacher. She hopes for a loan amount of NGN 150,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell

loans.name: Rose Kalunde

texts.en: For the last three years, Rose has been selling clothes, such as dresses, that are similar to other clothing dealers at Gikomba Market in Nairobi. The market specializes in secondhand clothes and is the biggest open air market in Kena. She has two employees and faces a transportation challenge when the rainy season arrives.  She will be using the requested loan of KES 20,000 to restock clothes.  Her dream is to be able to sell clothes internationally.  Rose is married and describes herself as hardworking and honest.

loans.use: To buy more clothes.

loans.name: Gela

texts.en:
Gela J. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and local beer and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell.  Gela is 23 years old and is married with a husband that is a business man.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: stock more bags of charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Joyce Mwelu

texts.en: Joyce sells secondhand clothes, such as skirts and T-shirts, to frequent customers and passers-by in the open-air Gikomba Market. She started this business six months ago after quitting her previous employment.   She has two employees.  Her business faces a challenge when rainy season arrives as her business is outdoors.  She will be using the requested loan of KES20,000 to buy a kiosk and restock clothes.  In the future, she wants to be a wholesaler.   Joyce is married and has a four year old daughter.  She describes herself as social, honest and trustworthy.

loans.use: To add more stock of clothes, shoes and buy a kiosk where she will be operating from.

loans.name: Ronald Shake

texts.en:
Ronald Shake is 41 years old and married to Eunice Charo. Together have a daughter named Carol.

Ronald's business is situated in Gongoni-Malindi and he sells retail goods which include items such as sugar, rice, milk and other household necessities. His business has been in operation for the last 12 years and earns a monthly profit of Kshs 8,000. He also runs a vegetable shop on the side which boosts on his income.

He was introduced to Kadet by a friend who was already a client. Ronald plans to add stock of flour, sugar and other items in the shop as well as supply paraffin to other retail shops with the loan that he has been advanced. He hopes to expand the business by opening another retail shop with the extra earnings from the business loan.

Ronald describes himself as a determined man with a heart to succeed and dreams of owning a wholesale shop that will cater for both small and large retail shops in Malindi.

loans.use: To add general stock of flour, sugar and parrafin for sale

loans.name: Kwasi

texts.en: Kwasi is thirty-two years old. He is a petty trader who trades in used clothes, selling of used clothing has a very big market in Ghana as brand new cloths are very expensive for the economically active poor. Therefore selling of used clothing has created a market for many men and women like Kwasi. He wants to use the loan to buys more bales of used clothing to increase his inventory. He believes this loan would help him expand his business.

loans.use: To purchase used clothing in bulk.

loans.name: Zainab Ali

texts.en: For the last six years, Zainab has been selling charcoal to frequent customers.  She has one employee and faces the business challenge of unreliable transportation of charcoal.  Her business is at Makongeni Phase 4, a semi-urban area near the town of Thika.  She will be using the requested loan of KES40,000 to buy more charcoal.  In addition, she sells clothes, such as jackets.  In the future, she wants to expand her business and own a car which she will use for transportation.  Zainab is divorced and has two children.  She describes herself as hardworking, jovial and innovative.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal.

loans.name: Agowa

texts.en:
Agowa P. is currently in the business of selling maize and millet flour and is requesting a loan to buy jerrycans of cooking oil to sell.  Agowa is 45 years old and is married with a husband that is a security guard. She has 8 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to educate her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: buy jerrycans of cooking oil to sell.

loans.name: Otuwa

texts.en:
Otuwa M. is currently in the business of selling beans, groundnut paste and green vegetables and is requesting a loan to buy more bags of beans and groundnut paste to sell.  Otuwa is 30 years old and is married with a husband that is a logician.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: buy more bags of beans and groundnut paste to sell.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther is 24 years old and married, with one child. Her child is currently in primary school. She supports herself and her child by selling cosmetics. Esther sells by “hawking,” a form of selling where the seller moves door-to-door while carrying her stock on the head. She says selling cosmetics is very lucrative and therefore she wants to expand her inventory to enable her make a good income and support her child’s education.

loans.use: To purchase cosmetics in bulk.

loans.name: Kiko

texts.en:
Kiko M. brews and sells local alcoholic beverages in a pub. Kiko is 20 years old and single.  She has 1 child, who does not attend school.  Kiko is requesting a loan to purchase more raw materials. With the extra profits that she expects as a result of the loan, she hopes to be able to open up a restaurant.
