BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To more materials to use

loans.name: Sylvester

texts.en:
Sylvester is 42 years old. He is a divorced with three children. He is a retailer of car spare parts and scraps. He buys his supplies from spare-parts dealers and sells on a retail basis to his customers. He enjoys his trade very much. However, he is handicapped by low working capital since prices have gone up. He therefore needs the loan to remain in business. 

He wants to use the loan to buy new stock of spare parts and scraps to serve his customers. He believes this will enable him to make a good income to expand his business.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts in bulk

loans.name: Agartha

texts.en: Agartha is twenty-eight years old and a mother with three girls. The children are currently in school. The selling of used clothing has a very big market in Ghana as brand new clothes are very expensive for the economically-active poor; therefore, selling used clothing has created a market for many women like Agartha. She wants to use the loan to buy more bales of used clothing to increase her inventory. She believes this loan will help her save for her children’s future and also to rent a store to trade.

loans.use: To purchase assorted used clothes.

loans.name: Hernan

texts.es:
Don Hernán tiene 26 años es una persona joven y dedicado a su trabajo el no está casado pero vive con la Gabriela que es la madre de su hijo pequeño de 2 años,  ellos viven en Huañacahua es una comunidad de Vinto al oeste del departamento de Cochabamba.

Don Hernán solicita el crédito para comprar un terreno que está cerca de su casa, para poder trabajar esas tierras y estar cerca de su casa y en especial cerca de su hijo pequeño. Hernán quiere estar con su hijo el mayor tiempo posible porque él fue abandonado por su padre cuando era un niño y no tiene ni un solo recuerdo de su padre él dice que su madre es todo para el por estar siempre a su lado.

El crédito otorgado también podrá incrementar sus ingresos ya que su actividad principal es la agricultura porque desde niño su madre le enseño y como segunda actividad la producción de leche junto con su esposa. También trabaja como albañil cuando no está en la agricultura, él trabaja mucho para darle una mejor vida a su pequeño y quiere en un futuro muy cercano poder casarse con Gabriela y seguir trabajando para poder ayudar a su madre.
texts.en:
Hernan is 26 years old and dedicated to his job. He is not married, but he lives with Gabriela, who is the mother of his two-year-old son. They live in Huañacahua, in the community of Vinto, west of the department of Cochabamba. Hernan is requesting this credit to purchase a plot of land close to his house, in order to be able to work the land while being close to his home and his son. He wants to be with his son as much as possible, because he was abandoned by his own father when he was a child and does not have a single memory of him. He says that his mother is everything to him, for always being by his side. This loan will also make it possible for him to increase his income, since his main activity is agriculture, which his mother taught him as a child. He also is involved in the production of milk, along with his wife. Additionally, he works as a mason when he is not working in agriculture. He works a lot to give his son a better life, and in the near future he would like to marry Gabriela and continue working to be able to help his mother.

Translated from Spanish by Mark Broscoe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase a plot of land for cultivation

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en: Beatrice is thirty-six years old. She is married with three children. Her children are currently in school. To support her household, she has been selling soft drinks in her neighborhood to her loyal customers. She says the selling of soft drinks is very lucrative and therefore, she wants to expand her inventory to enable her to make good income for her family’s needs.

loans.use: To purchase soft drinks in bulk.

loans.name: Espiritu Santo Group

texts.es:
Marco M. de aproximadamente 35 años, se dedica junto a su esposa a la elaboración de cera para piso, utilizando keresone, gasolina y parafina, de éstos el más difícil de conseguir es el último (parafina) se tiene que comprar por cantidad, sino no lo venden para lo cual necesitan el préstamo, ofrecen sus productos a diferentes empresas como bancos, entidades financieras, oficinas y otros. Ellos tienen esperanza de hacer crecer su negocio y que tenga muchos frutos.
Las demás integrantes del grupo Espíritu Santo que pertenecen al Centro Focal Los Andes cuentan con diversas actividades económicas de producción, comercialización y servicio.
texts.en:
Marcos M., who is approximately 35 years old, together with his wife, manufactures floor wax using kerosene, gasoline and paraffin. Paraffin is the most difficult to get of these ingredients; it must be purchased in bulk or it will be sold and unavailable. This is why they need financing. They sell their product to various businesses like banks, financial institutions, offices, and others. They hope to see their business grow and that it will yield many fruits. The other members of the Espíritu Santo group that are members of the Los Andes Focal Center have other commercial, production and service lines of work.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy raw materials (paraffin) and merchandise.

loans.name: Lani

texts.en:
Lani, 48, is a farmer in Banga, South Cotabato. She owns a 2-and-a-half hectare corn field and 1 carabao. The income she receives from the farm supports her 4 children. She would like to supply her farm with farm necessities but she lacks capital.

She joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to be able to avail of a loan. She requested 8,000 Php to purchase farm inputs. With this, she can sustain her farm as well as her family.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs

loans.name: A. Chimène

texts.fr: Z. A. Chimène est née en 1985 et vit depuis une dizaine d’année à Fiégnon à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à MONTCHO Basile, un pêcheur, Chimène est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés. Chimène vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Chimène n’a pas été à l’école. Pour faire face à ses besoins, Chimène vend depuis trois ans, des céréales (maïs, ris) et aussi de la farine de manioc, à son domicile. Chimène s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Chimène est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà obtenu trois crédits dans l’institution, crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. Chimène sollicite un quatrième crédit auprès de ALIDé, afin d’augmenter le stock de ses produits et de mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Z. A. Chimène was born in 1985 and for the past decade she has lived in Fiégnon in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is married to Montcho Basile, a fisherman. Chimène is the mother of two children, both of whom are attending school. Chimène lives with her husband and their children. Chimène did not attend school. In order to handle the family's needs, for the past three years Chimène has sold grains (corn, rice) and manioc flour from her home. Chimène supplies herself in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. Chimène is an old client of ALIDé, she has obtained three loans from the micro-finance institution, all of which she fully repaid. Chimène is requesting a fourth loan from ALIDé, in order to increase the stock of her products and better respond to the needs of her clientele.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase grains (sacks of corn and rice)

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en: Rosemarie has an agricultural business in Banga, South Cotabato. Now at the age of 43, she manages a corn field that is 2 hectares. She joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to request a loan of 8,000 Php to support her business. She is a mother of 5 children. She wants to improve her business in order to support her family. This loan will be very helpful to finance her business with a low interest.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs

loans.name: Akouavi Thérèse

texts.fr: A. Akouavi Thérèse est née en 1974 et vit depuis une vingtaine d’année à Fiégnon à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à GBEDOU Benoît un pêcheur, Akouavi Thérèse est mère de six enfants, tous scolarisés. Mais seulement quatre des enfants sont à sa charge. Akouavi Thérèse vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Akouavi Thérèse n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Depuis environs 20 ans, Akouavi Thérèse vend des céréales (maïs, riz) et aussi de la nourriture à son domicile. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Akouavi Thérèse s’approvisionne. Akouavi Thérèse a déjà bénéficié de trois crédits à ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés. Akouavi Thérèse voudrait élargir son activité, pour mieux répondre à la demande des clients. C’est la raison pour laquelle Akouavi Thérèse sollicite un quatrième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Akouavi Thérèse A. was born in 1974 and has lived for about twenty years in Fiégnon, Cotonou, economic capital of Benin. Married with Benoît GBEDOU, a fisherman, Akouavi Thérèse is mother of six children, who are all attending school. But she has to provide just for four of them. Akouavi Thérèse lives together with her children and her husband. The couple provides together for the family. Akouavi Thérèse did not attend school. For about twenty years she has sold in her house cereals, such as maize and rice, as well as food. She buys her supplies in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. Akouavi Thérèse received already from ALIDé three loans, that she fully repaid. Akouavi Thérèse would like to expand her business, in order to respond to customer demand, and for this reason she is requesting a fourth loan to ALIDé.

Translated from French by MONICA URBAN, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase bags of maize and rice.

loans.name: Melinde

texts.en:
Melinde D., 58 years old, has a sari-sari store and a farm. She wants to grow the size of her business in order to augment her family's income to support their daily needs. She has two adult children. She has been waiting for an opportunity to increase her capitalization so that she could venture onto other businesses.

She would like to apply for a loan of Php 8,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. The loan will really help in buying additional merchandise for her sari-sari store and farm supplies for her farm.

loans.use: To buy additional merchandise for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Geneviève

texts.fr: A. Geneviève est née en 1975 et vit depuis 25 ans environs à Fiégnon à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à BALOGOUN Chérif un géomètre, Geneviève est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés. Geneviève vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Geneviève n’a fait que l’école primaire. Il y a 12 ans déjà que Geneviève mène comme activité, la vente de poissons fumés et divers autres produits, au marché de Fiégnon. C’est au bord de la mer et aussi à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Geneviève s’approvisionne. Geneviève a déjà bénéficié de trois crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés. Geneviève voudrait augmenter son fonds de roulement et agrandir son activité. C’est pourquoi, Geneviève sollicite un quatrième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Geneviève A. was born in 1975 and has lived for 25 years in the vicinity of Fiégnon in Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. Married to Chérif BALOGOUN, a surveyor, Geneviève has two children, both at school. Geneviève lives with her children and her husband. The couple cover the household expenses between them. Geneviève has been to primary school only. For 12 years now Geneviève has been selling smoked fish and various other products at the market in Fiégnon. She gets her supplies at the seashore and also at Dantokpa, the international market of Bénin. Geneviève has already had three loans from ALIDé, all of which have been repaid without problem. Geneviève would like to increase her working capital and expand her business. It is for this reason that Geneviève is asking for a fourth loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fish

loans.name: Alfonso

texts.en: Alfonso, 39, has been in a rice farming business since 1986. He manages a 1-hectare farm in Banga, South Cotabato. He is a father of 2 children; the eldest is only 12 years old. He works hard in the farm to sustain his family. Having limited capital, he joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to avail of a loan. He requested a loan of 8,000 Php, enough to buy fertilizers and seeds. This will be helpful to him to continue with his farming business.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and seeds

loans.name: Aileen

texts.en: Aileen, 47, manages a 3-hectare corn field in Banga, South Cotabato. She's married to Henry and has 2 children. Together, they till the land to have a good harvest in the future. Aileen heard about Community Economic Ventures, Inc. that offers financial services to entrepreneurs. Later, she joined and requested 8,000 Php to purchase farm inputs. This loan has a low interest and is not burdensome for her to pay.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs

loans.name: Ceferina Berta

texts.es:
Ceferina T. de 60 años, vive en una casa de cemento, con todos los servicios básicos ubicado en la zona de la Perimetral de Guayaquil, Ceferina comenzó como comerciante informal en Pedro Pablo Gómez de Guayaquil, debido a que la ley Municipal no permitía estar en la calle laborando, decidió poner así su negocio en su vivienda.

Ahora Ceferina trabaja desde las 07h00 hasta las 19h00 vendiendo en su domicilio conjuntos para niños a $ 12.00 c/u, pantalones a $ 17.00 c/u y camisetas a $ 15.00 c/u, una de las mayores dificultades que tiene son los ladrones ya que tiene que estar pendiente de lo que tiene en su casa, su esposo trabaja como mensajero en una empresa farmacéuticas.

Con el préstamo quiere comprar $ 300.00 de pantalones, $ 160.00 conjunto para niños, $ 300.00 para camisetas, en su futuro quiere ubicar un local en el centro de la ciudad de Guayaquil, y terminar de construir su vivienda.
texts.en:
Ceferina T. is 60 years old and lives in a cement house, with all of the basic services, located in the zone of Perimetral de Guayaquil. She began as a casual trader in Pedro Pablo Gomez de Guayaquil. Due to the fact that municipal law did not allow working in the street, she decided to set up a business in her home. Now Caferina works from 7:00 A.M. until 7:00 P.M. selling clothing in her home. She sells childrens' outfits for $12.00 each, pants for $17.00, and shirts for $15.00 each. One of the greatest troubles she has are thieves, since he has to be watchful of the things in her house. Her husband works as a messenger for a pharmaceutical company. With this loan she wants to purchase $300.00 worth of pants, $160.00 of childrens' outfits, and $300.00 of shirts. In the future, she would like to establish a business in downtown Guayaquil and finish constructing her home.

Translated from Spanish by Mark Broscoe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase pants, childrens' outfits, and shirts for resale

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
Emma V. is a rice grower and a mother of one child. Her child is only 11 years old. As a mother, she wants to provide her child with a good education and a bright future. Her farm is what she earns income from to buy her family adequate supply of food, clothing and other basic needs.

She would like to apply for a loan of Php 8,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy all the needed farm supplies to grow her crops well. With her loan, she could expect better harvest in the farm.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies

loans.name: Twegatte Group, Kayunga

texts.en: K. Judith is the leader of her lending group in Kayunga. She is 51 years old and married with 3 children, aged 16 years (twins) and 15 years, and she takes care of 3 dependants. Judith has a poultry business where she has dealt in layers and selling eggs in Kikubamutwe for 10 years and she is able to make 20,000/= as weekly profits. She attributes her success to her hard work and good customer care and her goal is to expand her farm to have more chicken for rearing. Judith needs a loan to be able to buy more feed for her chickens.

loans.use: Buying more chicken feed for her birds.

loans.name: Myriam Rosa

texts.es:
En el barrio Altos de Betania de Sabanagrande Atlántico, caracterizado por tener viviendas levantadas  con el gran esfuerzo de sus habitantes mediante  el sistema de autoconstrucción, habita Myriam con su esposo, ella es una mujer de naturaleza comerciante, que inició su primer negocio en el año 1998, cuando su esposo quedó sin trabajo intempestivamente y debió ingeniárselas para cumplir con los compromisos familiares especialmente los relacionados con la educación de sus hijos y los gastos generales del hogar. Esta situación la llevo a descubrir su potencial empresarial y es así como por primera vez se dedica a comercializar productos de belleza adquiridos a través de una amiga, pues ella no podía hacerlo directamente porque no tenía dinero para iniciar y carecía de una historia crediticia por ser desconocida en el comercio. Gradualmente reunió un capital,  producto de su esfuerzo,  perseverancia y disciplina, que le sirvió para afiliarse a una empresa y poder exhibir productos mediante guías especializadas, construyendo así su propia clientela, que la impulsó a incursionar en la venta de otras mercancías  solicitadas  que no encontraban en la revista para la cual trabajaba. 

Con el  incremento de sus ingresos empezó a comprar por volúmenes pero su mercancía no estaba protegida, pues no tenia donde guardarlas y se le dificultaba el control de sus inventarios;esta forma de trabajar la mantenía mucho tiempo fuera de su hogar, razones por las que se esforzó para comprar vitrinas que protegieran sus productos y los exhibieran  en un sitio fijo, para ello pensó en abrirle un espacio a este propósito en su vivienda, una Miscelánea que todos en su barrio y en los alrededores ahora conocen. Ella ha superado muchas dificultades la mas difícil ocurrió cuando su negocio se mostró más próspero y tenia autosuficiencia sin necesidad de endeudarse, su pequeña nieta enfermó y parte de su capital lo dirigió a lograr la recuperación de su salud. Fue entonces cuando recurrió a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, por primera vez, para buscar apoyo. Su nueva financiación le ayudarà para comprar productos de belleza e higiene,adornos, ropa interior,detalles para el hogar y mercanciasa que aun vende a través de catálogos como vestidos para damas y caballeros.

Su máximo sueño es separar el negocio de su vida familiar para equilibrar efectivamente su vida laboral, personal y de hogar, planea organizar un local independiente de su casa y gradualmente comprar nuevos exhibidores de mercancía para ello Myriam trabajarà duplicando sus esfuerzos con el acompañamiento de su esposo.
texts.en:
Myriam lives with her husband in the Altos de Betania de Sabanagrande Atlántico neighborhood. The neighborhood is characterized by houses that were raised with great effort by its inhabitants. Myriam is a natural businesswoman. She started her first business in 1998 when her husband was suddenly left without work. She needed to figure out how to meet the family commitments, especially those related to her children’s education and the general household expenses. This situation led her to discover her business potential. That is how she came, for the first time, to sell beauty products that she got from a friend. She could not do it directly because she did not have money to start, and she lacked a credit history because she was not known in the business. Gradually, through her effort, perseverance, and discipline, she got together the capital to affiliate herself with a business. She was able to display her products through special guides and build her own customer base. This drove her to start selling other requested merchandise that could not be found in her business’ magazine. With the increase in earnings, she started to buy in bulk. But, her merchandise was not protected, and she did not have a place to store it. It was difficult to control her inventory. This work kept her away from home a lot. That is why she put forth much effort to buy display cases to protect her products and display them in a fixed place. She thought of opening a place in her home. It is a small general store, and everyone in the neighborhood and surrounding area knows it. She has overcome many difficulties. The most difficult happened when the business was more prosperous, and she was self-sufficient without the need of going into debt. Her little granddaughter became ill, and part of her capital went towards her granddaughter’s recuperation. That was when she turned to the Mario Santo Domingo Foundation, for the first time, to look for help. Her new loan will help her to buy beauty products, hygiene products, decorations, underwear, items for the home, and merchandise like clothing for women and men that she still sells through catalogs. Her biggest dream is to separate the business from her family life in order to effectively balance her work life and her personal home life. She plans to organize a place independent from her house and gradually buy new showcases for her merchandise. To do this, Myriam, with her husband, will work by doubling her efforts.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy beauty products, hygiene products, decorations, underwear, items for the home, and merchandise like clothing for women and men

loans.name: Maria Sandiego

texts.es:
La señora María llegó a la ciudad de Barranquilla desde  Sincé - Córdoba  donde vivía con sus padres, a casa de un hermano en la busqueda nuevos horizontes para poder ayudar a sus padres, inicialmente trabajó en oficios varios y simultáneamente se capacitó para poder superarse; así realizó cursos de primeros auxilios, actividad que le facilitó posteriormente su trabajo cuidando adultos mayores,  como su salud se deterioró por su ritmo de trabajo, debió buscar otra actividad que le generara ingresos y adaptada a su recuperación, es así como desde hace tres años, se inicia en la venta de productos a través de catálogos  que promociona a clientes del barrio Carlos Meisel y sus alrededores, sitios destacados por su amplia gama de negocios informales; ella, realiza una visita de preventa persona a personas,  exhibiendo sus productos mediante guías especializadas que le suministra la empresa a la cual está afiliada, conoce y explica las bondades de cada producto para generar la compra de ellos. Su dedicación  le ha generado un importante número de clientes a los que vende a crédito y recupera su cartera en plazos quincenales aunque también vende de contado de acuerdo al monto del pedido.

Una de las dificultades que manifiesta es que su capital de trabajo no responde al numero de pedidos requeridos por su clientela, por eso recurre a la financiación pues conoce su probabilidad de acceder a créditos porque ha construido una buena historia crediticia en la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, con quien viene trabajando desde  el año 2007. María manifiesta que con los créditos y el control de su endeudamiento, aprendido en la capacitación empresarial, ha logrado estabilizar sus ingresos. 
Su próxima meta es adquirir vitrinas, diversificar su mercancía y poner una miscelánea, pues considera que es bien reconocida en el suroccidente de Barranquilla y sus clientes necesitan un sitio fijo donde ubicarla, para ello se prepara observando su mercado  y estando atenta a nuevas oportunidades de productos que le generen mayor margen de utilidad. Su máximo desafío es tener una casa propia para independizarse, pero es una meta a largo plazo en la que no deja de pensar. Ella reconoce que desarrollar un negocio ha ido de la mano con su crecimiento personal, el cual se ve reflejado en la seguridad de si misma. 
 
El crédito inmediato, por valor de $500.000 lo va a emplear en surtir el negocio con cosméticos, multiusos, lencería  acordes a los pedidos de su clientela,  de esta manera  es oportuna y ofrece  un mejor servicio manteniéndolos satisfechos.
texts.en:
María left Sincé – Córdoba, where her parents lived, and went to her brother’s house in the city of Barranquilla to look for new horizons to be able to help her parents. She started working different jobs, and at the same time she received training to be able to improve herself. She took first aid courses, which later helped her get work taking care of elderly people. As her health deteriorated because of her work schedule, she needed to look for other work that would generate income and accommodate her recuperation. That is how she started selling products by catalog three years ago. She sells to customers in the Carlos Meisel neighborhood and the surrounding areas, which are known for their wide range of informal businesses. She makes pre-sales visits from person to person. She shows her products through specialized guides provided by the business she is affiliated with. She knows and explains the benefits of each product to generate its purchase. Her dedication has generated an important number of customers. She sells to them on credit, and she collect payments biweekly. She also sells for cash depending on the amount of the order. One of the difficulties she has is that her working capital does not correspond to the number of customer orders. That is why she turns to the loan. She knows her probability of getting loans because she has built a good credit history with the Mario Santo Domingo Foundation. She has been working with them since 2007. María demonstrates with her loans and the control of her debt that she has learned, through her business training, to stabilize her income. Her next goal is to get display cases, diversify her merchandise, and establish a general store. She is well known in the southwestern part of Barranquilla. Her customers need a fixed place to find her. To that end, she prepares by observing her market and being attentive to new opportunities for new products that will generate a larger margin of profit. Her biggest challenge is to have her own house to become independent. It is a long term goal, which she does not stop thinking about. She recognizes that the development of her business goes hand in hand with her personal growth. That is a reflection of her self-confidence. She will use the loan for 500,000 COP to stock her business with cosmetics, multipurpose items, and lingerie according to customer orders. This is expedient, and she will offer better service, which will keep her customers satisfied

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy cosmetics, multipurpose items, and lingerie

loans.name: Esperanza

texts.es:
Esperanza Cobo, nació hace 53 años en San Gil, Santander, pueblo  de gente amable, alegre y con una fuerte vocación comercial;  es una mujer activa, que  forma parte de la  Junta de Acción comunal de la localidad y  es delegada  de la Asociación que rige a las estructuras comunitarias de la ciudad; incursionó como comerciante  en el Popular Barrio Montes desde hace mas de cinco años, tiempo en el que se vinculó a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, con el deseo de formarse empresarialmente y obtener financiación  para vender productos a través de  catalogo. Desde esta época la Fundación le ha otorgado 4 (cuatro) créditos gradualmente aumentados al ser reembolsados; hace dos años, aprovecho la oportunidad de tener un negocio mas estable, pues su hermano por motivos de viaje  le cedió un local dotado de vitrinas y estantería en calidad de arriendo pero sin mercancía; en este sitio inició una droguería combinada con  variedades y la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo  le otorgó su segundo crédito por valor de $1.500.000  para ser cancelado en un plazo de 12 meses, con él surtió la droguería y muy pronto sus ingresos empezaron a incrementarse, debido al volumen de ventas que obtuvo, lo cual  le exigió dedicarse completamente a esta actividad; con esta experiencia ha fortalecido su desempeño comercial; su capacidad de observación y formación permanente le ha facilitado identificar un mercado potencial de productos de papelería, hacia el cual planea dirigir su estrategia de ampliación mercadologica. 

Su próximo préstamo de $ 2.300.000, lo emplearía en un 50% para comprar medicamentos alopáticos comunes, suplementos dietarios; cosméticos; productos de tocador, higiénicos y el otro 50% lo invertirá en compra de artículos de papelería, como lápices, cartulinas, hojas, bolígrafos, fólderes resaltadores, cuadernos agendas, portámemos, sacapuntas, papel periódico, carpetas,  CDS, tarjetas, reglas, juegos de oficina, considerado como su plan inmediato de mercadeo.

 Las condiciones de vida de Esperanza han mejorado notablemente; con sus esfuerzos su único hijo ha logrado estudiar y sostenerse en la facultad de música  en la Universidad del Atlántico, él es su máxima motivación, su sueño inmediato es que se convierta en un profesional, su próximo desafío es ampliar su negocio, arrendando un local contiguo a su negocio. Ella  aun vive en la casa paterna, es separada  y sus padres necesitan de su compañía. Su preocupación es la innovación constante, ajustada al requerimiento del mercado, pues siempre esta atenta en ofrecer a la clientela lo que la temporada exige, conoce perfectamente la estacionalidad  de cada grupo de los productos que vende y el comportamiento de su oferta se rige  por  los picos de alta comercialización individual.
texts.en:
Esperanza Cobo was born 53 years ago in San Gil, Santander. It is a town with affable, happy people and strong commercial activity. She is an active woman who is part of the Junta de Acción Communal in the area. She is a delegate to the Association that governs the community structures in the city. She started working as a businesswoman in the popular neighborhood of Montes over five years ago. During that time she connected with the Mario Santo Domingo Foundation in the hopes of getting business training and a loan to sell products by catalog. From that time on the Foundation has given her four loans. They were gradually increased as they were reimbursed. Two years ago she took advantage of the opportunity of having a more stable business. Her brother, because of travel, gave her a place in rental condition outfitted with display cases and shelves but without merchandise. She set up a drugstore with variety items at this place. The Mario Santo Domingo Foundation gave her the second loan for 1,5000,000 COP, which was to be repaid in 12 months. When the drugstore was stocked, her earnings started to increase very quickly. Her volume of sales required her to devote herself completely to this activity. This experience has strengthened her business performance. Her capacity to observe and the permanent formation of her business have allowed her to identify a potential market for paper products. She is planning to direct her strategy towards increasing her merchandise. She will use 50% of her next loan for 2,300,000 COD for common allopathic medicine, dietary supplements, toiletries, and hygiene products. She will use the other 50% to buy stationery items like pencils, cardboard, sheets of paper, pens, folders, highlighters, notebooks, agendas, memos, pencil sharpeners, newspapers, binders, CDs, cards, and office sets. This is her merchandise plan for now. Esperanza’s life conditions have notably improved. Through her efforts she has been able to support her only child, and he has been able to study music at the Atlántico University. He is her greatest motivation. Her immediate dream is that he becomes a professional. Her next challenge is to expand her business by renting the location next to her business. She still lives in her father’s house. She is separated, and her parents need her company. She worries constantly about innovation and adjusting to the market’s requirements. She always attempts to offer her customers the seasonal requirements. She knows perfectly the seasonal conditions for each group of products that she sells. Her offers are governed by the peaks of seasonal customer demand.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy merchandise for her drugstore and for her stationery business

loans.name: Maria Del Carmen

texts.es:
María del Carmen  M.  R., nació y habita en el barrio Barlovento de Barranquilla, antiguo comunidad de invasión, altamente vulnerable y caracterizado por la actividad de reciclaje. Desde pequeña estuvo vinculada con la actividad de elaboración de alimentos, porque que sus padres  ejercían este oficio a las afueras de la antigua intendencia fluvial, que funcionaba en el sector, por su cercanía con un brazo del rio mas largo de Colombia “El Magdalena”.
Hija  mayor de cuatro hermanos vivió con su madre el  abandono de su padre, fue asi como se vio en la necesidad de ayudar en los quehaceres domésticos y en los propios del negocio cuando apenas contaba con 10 años de edad, para poder sacar a delante a sus hermanos menores, esto impidió que estudiara, pues la lectura y escritura  no era su necesidad práctica y no era importante en la concepcion familiar  de esa época. 
Replicando la historia de sus padres, María del Carmen después de comprometerse tuvo hijos gemelos y al principio su cónyuge suplía las necesidades básicas de su familia,   pero en corto tiempo los abandonó, teniendo que trabajar fuertemente para sacar adelantea su familia; sin estudios y con el conocimiento del oficio aprendido desde niña,  comenzó a vender  arepas de huevo, empanadas, caribañola  y comida rápida en los pueblos cercanos donde se realizaran las  fiestas patronales. De la mano de una segunda relación, que por su muerte duró muy poco, construyó su casa, educó a sus hijos hasta llevarlos a realizar una carreta técnica y  con el correr del tiempo adquirió el restaurante que su madre dejó al fallecer  el que hoy funciona en su vivienda y en él trabajan su  hija y  su hermana.
Apoyada financieramente por la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, con dos créditos reembolsados exitosamente, ha logrado adecuar la infraestructura de su negocio haciendo mejoras locativas.  Con su  tercer crédito, Maria comprará sillas, utensilios,  pues ha aumentado su clientela y cuando llegan deben esperar a que se desocupen los espacios donde almorzar y en ese momento todo se vuelve un caos;  igualmente  invertirá en la compra arroz,costillas de cerdo,tocino, pollo vinagre,aceite, verduras y alcaparras que son los ingredientes para elaborar pasteles, hayacas o comidas especiales,armadas con hojas de bijao, que es una de sus especialidades y asi aprovecharà  la costumbre de consumos que tiene la clientela en estas épocas del año, para aumentar sus ventas.
María De la mano de su hija  que la apoya en la lecto escritura, participa en proceso formativos empresariales   y juntas aplican lo aprendido en beneficio del restaurante.  En ella,  resaltamos su alegria, tenacidad, su labor de amor, entrega, sacrificio y trabajo constante,   pues se ha sobrepuesto a la adversidad  para bridarle a su familia un mejor bienestar;  su mayor anhelo es que sus hijos puedan continuar con el negocio, tecnificado y perpetuándolo atreves de las nuevas generaciones, su mayor preocupación es la inestabilidad laboral  que reina y pone en riesgo la cartera, por ellos dirige sus esfuerzos a conservar sus mejores clientes y a conseguir mayor numero de aquellos que compren de contado para minimizar el riesgo
texts.en:
María del Carmen M. R. was born in and lives in the Barlovento neighborhood of Barranquilla. It is an ancient community, which was invaded. It is extremely vulnerable. It is characterized by the activity of recycling. Since she was little she was involved in making food because her parents did. They did this on the outskirts of the ancient town river. They worked in this area because of its proximity to a branch of the largest river in Colombia, El Magdalena. She is the oldest of four siblings. She lived with her mother and the abandonment of her father. That is why she saw the need to help with the household chores and with the business when she was barely ten years old. She helped in order to get her younger siblings ahead. This prevented her from going to school. Reading and writing were not a practical necessity, and they were not important to the families of that era. Repeating her parents’ history, María del Carmen had twins after becoming engaged. At first, her spouse supplied the basic family necessities. But, after a short amount of time he abandoned them. She had to work very hard to get her family ahead. Without an education, and with the knowledge of the work she learned as a child, she started to sell “arepas de huevo” (egg-filled savory corn cakes), empanadas, “caribañola” (small pie made with dough or puree of yucca that is filled with stew like ingredients and then fried), and fast food in the towns that are close to where the festivities for the national holidays are held. As a result of her second relationship, which lasted a short amount of time because he died, she built a house and educated her children until they had a technical career. As time went by, she acquired the restaurant that her mother left her when she died. The restaurant is now in her house, and her daughter and her sister work there. Financially helped with two loans, which she successfully repaid, from the Mario Santo Domino Foundation, she has been able to make on-site improvements to the infrastructure. With her third loan, María will buy chairs and utensils. Her customers have increased, and when they arrive they have to wait for empty spaces to eat. Everything then turns into chaos. She will also buy rice, pork ribs, bacon, chicken, vinegar, oil, vegetables, and capers; which are the ingredients for making pies, “hayacas” (cornmeal, meat and vegetables wrapped in banana leaves) or special foods; which are made from bijao leaves. This is one of her specialties. This way she takes advantage of the consumer habits that the customers have this time of year, and she will increase her sales. María’s daughter helps her with reading and writing to participate in the business trainings. Together they apply what they have learned to benefit the restaurant. Her happiness, tenacity, love of work, deliverance, sacrifice and constant work stand out to us. She has overcome adversity to give her family an improved well being. Her greatest goal is that her children be able to continue with the business. The business will be technically updated and perpetuated through the new generations. Her greatest worry is the labor instability that reigns and puts the economy at risk. Therefore, they direct their efforts towards keeping their best customers and getting a greater number of customers to buy with cash to minimize the risk.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy chairs, utensils, and ingredients to make food and her specialties

loans.name: Gloria Ines

texts.es:
Gloria es una mujer emprendedora que resiD. en la Urbanización el Río, municipio D. soledad (Atlántico), tiene 62 años D. edad y vive con su esposo y dos D. sus siete hijos. Aprendió una D. las actividades productivas mas tradicionales en esta tierra, desD.  hace aproximadamente 34 años ayudando a su madre en la confección D. cojines que vendía  a almacenes D. muebles y decoraciones. 

Inició su negocio, con una máquina D. coser, sencilla y D. segunda, fabricando tendidos para camas, que vendía a familiares y conocidos que encargaban estos producto; hoy  confecciona además D. tendidos vistosos edredones, bolsos y cojines, actividad que le ha reportado importantes ingresos para apoyar la educación D. sus siete hijos hasta terminar el bachillerato. 

Con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, Gloria ha obtenido 15 créditos desD. el año 1993; el menor y  primer crédito por valor D. $160.000.oo y el mayor por $3’000.000; su comportamiento D. pago es excelente; conoce los picos altos D. su negocio y D. la mano D. su asesor analiza  la relación costo-beneficio D. cada  crédito, en esta oportunidad requiere  $ 1.000,000 para invertirlo en telas y  forros para elaborar tendidos y sobrecamas abullonados que venderá por encargos que han realizado sus clientes.

Ella ha aprovechado las oportunidades D. financiamiento, para invertirlos en capital D. trabajo y compró una maquina D. coser nueva con la que incursionó recientemente en la confección D. edredones o sobrecamas abullonados. Su sueño es ampliar su  taller y comercializar en su propio almacén en compañía D. su hija mayor, para que no se pierda la tradición familiar. Gloria es una mujer sabia, honesta y cuida muy bien sus relaciones con las entidades y personas que la han apoyado y ademas es una madre ejemplar que ha transmitido a sus hijos el valor D. la responsabilidad y autosuficiencia, por eso ellos con sus propios esfuerzos han continuado estudiando.
texts.en:
Gloria is an enterprising woman who lives in Urbanización el Río, Soledad municipality, (Atlántico department). She is 62 years old and lives with her husband and two of her seven children. She learned one of the most productive skills common to this part of the country over 34 years ago from her mother: cushion making. These were sold to furniture and home decorating stores. She began her business with just one, simple, used sewing machine making bedspreads that she would sell to acquaintances and family members who ordered the items from her. Today, besides bedspreads, she makes attractive comforters, purses and cushions. This line of work has provided her important earnings which she has used to help pay for her seven children's education through high school. Since 1993, Gloria has had 15 loans from Fundación Mario Santo Domingo. The first and smallest of which was for $160,000.00, and the largest for $3'000,000. Her repayment history is excellent. She is aware of the high peaks in her business and, together with her advisor, analyzes the cost benefit ratio of each loan. On this occasion, she needs $1,000,000 to be used to buy fabric and lining to make bedspreds and quilted bed covers that she will sell based on her customers' orders. She has taken advantage of the financing opportunities to invest in working capital. She bought a new sewing machine that allowed her recently to start making comforters and quilted bedspreads. Her dream is to enlarge her workshop and to be able to sell in her own store with her eldest daughter so that the family tradition will be preserved. Gloria is a wise and honest woman that is careful to nurture her relationships with the institutions and persons that have helped her. Besides, she is an exemplary mother who transmits to her children the value of resposibility and self-sufficiency which has led them to continue their studies thanks to their own efforts.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fabric and lining.

loans.name: Elizabeth Maria

texts.es:
Elizabeth María A., es la segunda de una familia conformada por cuatro hermanos, es casada  y tiene una hija de 13 años en Noveno grado de secundaría, vive en Galapa pueblo que la vio nacer y uno de los más antiguos del Departamentos del Atlántico, con una gran riqueza cultural, donde las máscaras en madera y papel mache, las artesanías de bejuco, la confección, pintura en tela  y la danza son actividades que recogen la tradición de sus habitantes y enriquecen una de las fiestas mas importantes de Colombia, como lo es el Carnaval de Barranquilla, ciudad ubicada a 15 minutos de Galapa..  
  
Elizabeth María, cursó hasta Segundo año de primaria y aprendió a comunicarse con sus familiares y particulares por el lenguaje de señas de una forma empírica, debido a que no realizó estudios pertinentes como persona en condición de discapacidad auditiva. Pero su familia, eje principal de su crecimiento personal, la ayudó a identificar sus potencialidades realizando cursos técnicos en pintura, lo que le permitió iniciar tres años después, un pequeño negocio de manualidades, decoración y pinturas en tela, con el que ha desarrollado su autoconfianza y autosuficiencia. Así, con su inmenso deseo de superación y ese especial estimulo afectivo, aprendió a coser en una maquina familiar y hoy elabora prendas de vestir a los que le aplica las técnicas aprendidas como valor agregado y son productos alternos que han ampliado su mercado y que ha logrado con el apoyo financiero de la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo entidad con la que esta vinculada hace tres (3) años

En la actualidad espera recibir un préstamo por valor de $1.500.000 que reembolsará en un plazo de 18 meses, 45% del cual invertirá en pañolenci, lentejuelas, mostacillas y variedad de aplicaciones, con un brillo exclusivo para  adornar las viviendas y a las familias en la época navideña, con manteles, cojines, sabanas, fundas, edredones, toallas, almohadas, baja ollas, tapetes, cortinas y diversos cuadros que embellecen los hogares de quienes lo han solicitado; el 55% restante, lo invertirá en telas para elaborar vestidos sobre pedidos, que sus clientes usaran en estas fiestas. Elizabeth proyecta  en esta época de alta comercialización aumentar  sus ventas y con la  utilidad esperada ahorrará para pagar el crédito, los gastos  del colegio de su hija del año 2010 y reinvertirá de acuerdo con la época que se avecina en los meses de Enero y febrero, relacionada con el ingreso de los estudiantes al colegio y las fiestas del Carnaval de Barranquilla simultáneamente.

Elizabeth María, es una excelente miembro de familia y muy responsable en el cumplimiento de sus obligaciones financieras, durante 3 años que lleva accediendo a tres créditos de la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo los ha rembolsado oportunamente, porque los direcciona  al aumento de su capital de trabajo para poder crecer y sostenerse. Ella sueña a mediano plazo con tener un local y  una  nueva maquina  de coser que permita dar un mejor acabado a las prendas y fortalecer su mercado en otras localidades cercanas, pero reconoce que debe esperar hacer unos esfuerzos mayores de incursión comercial  para poder cumplir sus metas.
texts.en:
Elizabeth María A. is the second of four siblings. She is married and has a 13-year-old daughter who is in 9th grade. She lives in Galapa, her home town, and one of the oldest in Atlántico department. It is rich in cultural history, especially the wood and papier mache masks, woven reed crafts, sewing, painting on fabric, and dance. These activities gather the traditions of its inhabitants and enrich Colombia’s most famous festivals like the Carnival in Barranquilla, a city that is located 15 minutes away from Galapa. Elizabeth María finished second grade and taught herself in an empirical way how to communicate with her family and others using signs because, being hearing impaired, she never had the proper training in these skills. But her family, who are her guiding posts with respect to her personal development, helped her to realize her potential by providing her with technical painting courses. This allowed her, three years later, to be able to set up a small crafts business which consists of decoration and painting of fabrics. With this, her self-esteem and her self-sufficiency grew. Thus, with her immense desire to better herself and the loving support of her family, she learned how to sew on a family sewing machine and today she makes articles of clothing on which she applies the learned skills as value added. These are alternative products that have expanded her market and that have been made possible thanks to financial support from Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, with whom she has been associated for the last 3 years. Currently, she hopes to receive a loan for $1.500.000 that will be repaid in 18 month. 45% of it will be used to buy felt appliqués, sequins, beads, and a variety of other appliqués specially selected to decorate homes and families during the Christmas season with tablecloths, cushions, sheets, comforters, towels, pillows, trivets, throw rugs, curtains, and pictures that beautify the homes of those that request them. 55% will be used to buy fabric to make dresses on order that her customers will wear during these festivities. Elizabeth projects that this high sales season will increase her profits from which she will save enough to repay the loan, pay for her daughter’s 2010 school expenses and still have some to reinvest for the January and February seasons that are approaching, which are related to back-to-school and Carnival in Barranquilla. Elizabeth María is an excellent family member and very responsible with respect to her financial obligations. She has had 3 loans in the three years that she has been getting loans from Fundación Mario Santo Domingo; she has always repaid them in a timely fashion because she invests them in her business to grow and sustain herself. She hopes in the not too distant future to have a workshop and a new sewing machine that will permit her to make still better finishings on her clothing and to strengthen her market in nearby locations but she knows that she might have to make greater efforts to make commercial inroads if she is to reach her goals.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fabric, thread, pañolenci (felt appliqués), sequins, beads, and a variety of other appliqués for handicrafts and seasonal costumes.

loans.name: Celina Leonor

texts.es:
Celina M., nació en Magangue, puerto ubicado sobre el río Magdalena, desD. el cual emigró hace casi 30 años hacia la ciudad D. Barranquilla en busca D. mejores oportunidades, ubicándose en el barrio el Romance, sector en ese momento muy deprimido y sin servicios públicos básicos.

Como mujer jefa D. hogar, comenzó su negocio porque sus ingresos no eran suficientes para financiar los gastos familiares y se arriesgo a pedir prestado dinero a un particular para vender mercancías sobre pedido; visitaba a potenciales clientes, indagaba sus necesidades y una vez reunidos los pedidos, compraba las mercancías para distribuirla a crédito puerta a puerta, definiendo un plan D. pago con fechas concertadas, en las que cumplidamente realizaba las visitas D. cobro D. su cartera. Esta es la dinámica  que aun predomina y que hoy combina con la atención desD. un espacio D. su vivienda que adecuo con una vitrina para almacenar los productos. 

Con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo ha recibido 26 microcréditos aumentados gradualmente, por el buen manejo que D. ellos hace, pues los ha inyectado a su capital D. trabajo y le han servido para mejorar la infraestructura D. su vivienda y sostener a su hogar. El tener este negocio le ha representado seguridad D. si misma e independencia y capacidad D. poder ayudar a su familia. 
Con su nuevo crédito D. 18 meses por valor D. $1.300.000, planea la compra D. perfumes, calzado, cosméticos, telas, cubrelechos y accesorios femeninos para satisfacer la demanda actual D. sus clientes reales.  
Su próximo desafío es mejorar las instalaciones D. su vivienda con la utilidad generada por el crédito, reconoce que esta es una época en que la mercancía rota rápidamente y D. contado; ella es una adulta mayor muy activa, responsable y honesta, que a sus 78 años aun desempeña el rol central D. su hogar; resiD. con dos D. sus hijas, yernos y nietos. 
En la Actualidad Celina Leonor coordina el grupo “ Nuevo  Horizonte”, creado con el fin D. reunir a adultos mayores, con el apoyo D. la Alcaldía D. Barranquilla, en esta tarea participa con mas D. 200 personas del sur occidente y D. ellos un 40% son sus clientes con quien  participa en  actividades lúdicas, recreativas,  D. salud y capacitación; ella es una gran líder comunitaria, gestiona ayudas y procesos ante las autoridades competentes y sabe combinar esta tarea con las propias D. su actividad económica.
texts.en:
Celina M. was born in Magangue, a port on the Magdalena River. Almost 30 years ago she emigrated to the city of Barranquilla searching for better opportunities. She settled in the El Romance neighborhood, a very marginal area that doesn’t even have basic services. As a female head of household, she began her business because her income was insufficient to cover family expenses. She risked borrowing money from a private individual to start selling merchandise on order. She would visit potential customers, find out their needs and, once she had all the orders, would buy the merchandise and then distribute it door-to-door where she would leave them on credit. She would sketch out a payment plan with set collection dates when she would revisit her customers to collect her debts. This is the same methodology she uses to this day although now she also has a space in her home that she set up as a sales shop equipped with a showcase where she displays her wares. The Fundación Mario Santo Domingo has granted her 26 gradually larger microloans thanks to the good management of them she has. She has used them to improve the infrastructure of her house and to support her household’s expenses. Having this business has meant self-assurance and independence for her and has allowed her to help her family. With her new $1.300.000 loan, payable in 18 months, she plans to buy perfumes, footwear, cosmetics, fabrics, bedspreads, and women’s accessories to meet actual customers’ needs. Her next challenge is to improve her home’s condition with the profits generated from her sales. She realizes that this is the time of year when merchandise has high turnover and sales are in cash. She is an older, very active, responsible, and honest woman who, at the age of 78, still plays a central role in her home; she lives with two of her daughters, her sons-in-law and grandchildren. Currently, Celina Leonor is the “Nuevo Horizonte” group leader. It was formed to gather older adults, with the support of Barranquilla’s Mayor’s office. She participates with more than 200 persons from the south-west. Of these, 40% are her customers, with whom she shares leisure activities, recreation, health and training courses. She is a great community leader. She negotiates help and other bureaucratic processes before authorities and she knows how to combine this task with her economic activity.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy perfume, footwear, cosmetics, fabric, bedspreads, and women’s accessories.

loans.name: Yadira Patricia

texts.es:
En el popular barrio  Nueva Esperanza, habitado por gente alegre y solidaria,    vive Yadira Y., con su esposo y sus dos pequeños hijos. Ella, es propietaria  de una peluquería denominada “Sala de belleza Mente y Arte”. Allí, ofrece los servicios de manicure, pedicure, Blower, tratamiento capilar y corte de cabello, principalmente. Su idea de negocio empezó a funcionar hace ocho años, cuando aun  no tenía un establecimiento abierto al público, porque ofrecía sus servicios a domicilio. 
En Diciembre del año 2008 hizo su primer crédito en la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo por un valor de $1.200.000 que lo invirtió en la adecuación de su salón de belleza en su propia vivienda, dándole forma a su negocio. En esta oportunidad espera invertir su crédito por el mismo valor en la compra de un multimueble, para mejorar el lava cabeza, comprar productos que utiliza para sus clientes e invertir en publicidad y estimular a un mayor mercado.

El gran propósito de Yadira es modernizar su salón de belleza, por eso planea a mediano plazo adquirir tecnología que le facilite asesorar a sus clientes y contratar personal para generar mayores ingresos y fuente de empleo.  Ella conoce muy bien su trabajo, por eso extiende sus jornadas laborales en épocas de máxima productividad y realiza promociones especiales en los días menos concurridos. La excelente calidad de sus servicios le ha facilitado su posicionamiento en el mercado objetivo, impacto que se ha visto reflejado  principalmente en la estabilidad personal y familiar porque se han incrementado los ingresos en su hogar .

Durante el siguiente año está programada en el proceso formativo empresarial de la Fundación, ella cada día se preocupa por aprender a controlar sus operaciones administrativas, evaluar su capacidad de endeudamiento y construir herramientas mercadológicas, por eso su negocio se proyecta  como una unidad sólida y es que Yadira es una mujer organizada y muy responsable.
texts.en:
Yadira Y. lives with her husband and two small children in the Nueva Esperanza neighborhood, a popular area inhabited by cheerful and mutually supportive people. She has a beauty salon called “Sala de Belleza Mente y Arte.” She offers manicure, pedicure, hair drying, hair treatment, and hair cutting services, primarily. She started her business 8 years ago when she didn’t have a shop open to the public; she would go to her customers’ homes to provide services. In December, 2008, she took out her first loan with Fundación Mario Santo Domingo. It was for $1.200.000, which she used to equip a salon in her home. This time she hopes to use this loan, for the same amount, to buy a beautician’s station, to improve the shampooing station, to buy products she uses with her customers, and to invest in publicity to reach a wider market. Yadira’s main goal is to modernize her beauty salon. In the immediate future she wants to acquire the technology that will help her to better assess her customers’ needs and to hire personnel to generate higher income and to be a source of employment. She knows her work very well; that’s why she extends her working days during periods of maximum productivity and she has special promotions on the less busy days. The excellent quality of her services has situated her well in the marketplace, a reality that is reflected in her personal and family stability because household income has increased. During the next year she is scheduled to participate in the Fundación’s business development program. Thanks to the fact that Yadira is an organized and responsible woman, she attempts daily to learn how to manage her administrative operations, to evaluate her debt capacity, and to design marketing strategies to make her business a solid enterprise.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a beautician station, improve the shampoo station, buy products she uses with her customers, and invest in publicity to widen her market's area.

loans.name: Libeth

texts.es:
Libeh M., vive arrendada en una pequeña pero acogedora vivienda  del  Barrio Las Colonias de Barranquilla, estudió enfermería técnica, pero nunca la ejerció, pues su primer esposo murió y debió  sostener sus niños pequeños, con ingresos rápidos, por eso desde el año 2001, se dedicó a la comercialización de vestidos, prendas y perfumes, actividad que la ayudó a descubrir su potencial de mujer emprendedora, con la que ha crecido personalmente e  incrementado sus ingresos familiares y con la  que ahora se siente feliz.

Desde el año 2003 Libeh y Guillermo, su nuevo cónyuge, hombre de negocio, dedicado a la producción de calzado artesanal en un taller ubicado en el sitio de su vivienda,  vienen trabajando en la comercialización de los productos que él elabora y que es hoy el mayor negocio de esta unidad comercial. Su mercado está constituido por colmenas que venden en el Centro de Barranquilla y en otras ciudades del país. 

Libeh,  ha recibido dos créditos de la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo y este último por valor de $2.000.000, lo invertirá principalmente lo invertirá principalmente en materias primas para que su conyuge elabore calzado que sus clientes le han pedido, para comprar prendas en plata, y mercancía variada tambien a solicitud de sus clientes, que la conocen y esperan adquirir prendas de vestir bien combinadas con accesorios  y apropiados para cada momento; Ella, conoce perfectamente su mercado y los asesora generando así valor agregado. 

El sueño de esta familia, es adquirir una vivienda propia y por eso se han postulado para solicitar el subsidio que otorga el estado nacional a familias vulnerable e inscrito en el  programa Sueños y oportunidades en la urbanización  Villas de San Pablo, que lidera la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, porque planean comprar un lote para tener su propio casa y local al mismo tiempo y dejar de gastar en arriendo, para ello, trabajan buscando oportunidades de negocios  en plazas municipales en las que aun no han incursionado.
texts.en:
Libeh M. rents a small but cozy house in the Las Colonias de Barranquilla neighborhood. She studied nursing, but she has never worked as a nurse because her first husband died and she had to provide for her young children with faster money. So, since 2001 she has worked selling dresses, clothing, and perfumes. This work has helped her to discover her potential as an enterprising woman. She has grown on a personal level and has increased her family income so that she now feels happy. Since 2003, Libeh y Guillermo (her new husband, who makes hand-made shoes in a workshop located at their house) have been selling the products that he makes and this is now the main business for this household. Their market is mainly in market stalls located in the center of Barranquilla and in other cities around the country. Libeh has recieved two loans from the Fundación Mario Santo Domingo [Kiva Field Partner]. The last one was for 2,000,000 COP, which she will invest mainly in raw materials so that her husband can make the shoes that his clients have requested; in silver jewelry; and in a variety of merchandise that her clients have requested from her. Her clients know her and expect that she will find them clothing ítems that combine well with accesories and that are appropriate for different occasions. She knows her market very well and she advises her clients in a way that is valuable to them. This family’s dream is to buy their own house and they are planning to request the subsidy that the government grants to vulnerable families and to enroll in the Dreams and Opportunities program in the Villas de San Pablo development, which is run by the Fundación Mario Santo Domingo. They plan to purchase a lot so they can have their own house and business in one, so they can quit spending on rent. In order to do this, they are always looking for business opportunities in towns where they haven’t gone yet.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She will invest it mainly in raw materials so that her husband can make the shoes that his clients have requested; in silver jewelry; and in a variety of merchandise that her clients have requested from her

loans.name: Frederick

texts.en:
Frederick D. has one child who is 15 years old. He works everyday in the farm to support their daily needs. His dream for his child is to graduate from college; that is why he is doing the best he can to be productive to pay the fees and for books for school.

He is hoping to receive a loan of Php 5,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. He will use the loan to buy all the farm supplies needed to have an abundant harvest.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Akwata Empola Group, Kayunga

texts.en:
L. Juliet's business is basically mending old clothes and making new ones on order for her customers and for display. She is happy to have won over many clients due to her clean and tidy work. She is 45 years old and married with four children, ages 17, 15, 11, and 10, and she takes care of her own siblings.

Juliet is a hardworking and devoted lady with a tailoring business. She also sells clothes from Kayunga. Her goal is to be able to win tenders from various schools and institutions as well as to have a healthy family. She hopes to increase her stock as well as educate her children towards a brighter future. Juliet needs a loan to be able to buy more clothing materials for her business.

loans.use: To buy clothing materials for tailoring and resale

loans.name: Kristine

texts.en:
Kristine L. is 32 years old. She manages a small sari sari (general store) business which gives her the opportunity to sell a variety of goods and to earn income for her family. She is still single and she supports her siblings and nieces. The income she makes in her sari sari store not only helps her in terms of providing for her needs but also for the needs of her parents and siblings. 

She would like to apply for a loan of Php 8,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy additional merchandise so she can offer her customers a wider variety of selections.

loans.use: To buy additional merchandise for her sari sari (general store) business.

loans.name: Michelle Maria

texts.es:
Michelle García de 21 años de edad, vive en barrio marginal de Fortín de Guayaquil, Michelle comenzó ya hace 4 años en la florida de Guayaquil vendiendo en una pequeña tienda, pero como tuvo que cambiarse de sector lo puso en la que ahora es su casa ya hace 2 años.

Ahora Michelle trabaja desde las 06h00 hasta 22h00, en su tienda tiene arroz a $ 0.30 la libra, Pollo a $ 1.40 la libra, aceites $ 0.65 c/u, una de las mayores dificultades en su negocio son los racionamientos de energía del Gobierno, su esposo tiene 28 años el trabaja en el mercado de Sauces 9 de Guayaquil, con el tiene 2 hijos uno de 1 año y otro de 3 años.

Con el préstamo quiere comprar arroz, pollos, colas, para agrandar mas el negocio, en el futuro quiere poner una tienda muy surtida y también un gabinete por lo que Michelle se encuentra estudiando esa profesión.
texts.en:
Michelle G. is 21 years old and lives in the neighborhood of Fortin in the outlying areas of Guayaquil. Four years ago, she began selling products in a small store in Guayaquil, but since she had to change locations, she has been running the store from her house for the last two years. Now Michelle works from 6:00 A.M. until 10:00 P.M. In her store she has rice at $.30 a pound, chicken at $1.40 a pound, and oils at $.65 each. One of the greatest difficulties for her business is government rationing of energy. Her husband is 28 years old and works in Sauces 9 market in Guayaquil. With him she has two children; a one-year-old and a three-year-old. With this loan she wants to buy rice, chicken, and soft drinks to expand her business. In the future she would like to set up a well-stocked store with an office, for which she is currently studying this profession.

Translated from Spanish by Mark Broscoe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase rice, chicken, and oil for her business

loans.name: Loly

texts.en:
Loly C. is a rice grower. She manages a small parcel of land hoping to provide her family with enough income to buy their daily needs. Loly has only one child, who is 11 years old. She is doing her best to be able to send her child to school and be able to provide a better future to her family.

She is hoping to receive a loan of Php 8,000 from Community Economic Ventures to grow her crop well by buying all the farm supplies she needs.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Gregoria Fernandina

texts.es:
Gregoria tiene 57 años D. edad, es casada y vive con la última D. sus seis hijos en el distrito D. Paiján, provincia D. Ascope, en la región La laibertad, ubicada a tres horas D. la ciudad D. Chiclayo.

DesD. hace tres años se encuentra al cargo D. una bodega instalada en su casa, allí ofrece bebidas gaseosas y golosinas a sus habituales clientes. Ella nos comenta que el negocio originalmente era D. una D. sus hijas que tuvo que viajar al país D. Chile a trabajar, al partir ella se lo dejó encargado y desD. entonces lo ha sacado adelante.

Este negocio constituye una ayuda importante a la economía D. su familia ya que su esposo trabaja como peón agrícola y los ingresos que percibe no son suficientes para solventar los gastos familiares. Gregoria desea ampliar su negocio con la venta D. abarrotes pero no cuenta con el capital suficiente para realizar esta acción, por lo que se ha visto en la necesidad D. solicitar por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito D. 1000 nuevos soles.

Su más granD. anhelo es mejorar la construcción D. su casa, por ello desea seguir trabajando en su bodega, Gregoria es una mujer alegre, trabajadora y muy estimada por sus vecinos.
texts.en:
Gregoria is 57 years old, married, and lives with the youngest of her six children in the district of Paijan, province of Ascope, in the region La Libertad, located three hours from the city of Chiclayo. For three years she has been in charge of a grocery store set up in her house, in which she offers soft drinks and candy to her clients. She tells us that the business originally belonged to one of her daughters who had to travel to Chile to work. Since then, she has managed it and moved it forward. This business is a big help economically, since her husband is a farm worker and the income he receives is not enough to cover the family's expenses. Gregoria desires to expand her business with the sale of groceries, but she doesn't have enough capital to carry this out. Therefore, she sees it necessary to request for the first time from Edpyme Alternativa a loan of 1,000 nuevos soles. Her greatest wish is to improve the construction of her house, for which she wants to keep working in her grocery store. Gregoria is a happy and hard-working woman who is well respected by her neighbors.

Translated from Spanish by Mark Broscoe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase groceries to expand her business

loans.name: Joseph Okero

texts.en: Joseph runs a general shop, where he sells household goods to residents and walk-ins at Mukuru kwa Njenga, a slum area.  He has been in this business for the last three years.  His faces the business challenge of lack of funds to restock the goods sold.  He will use the requested loan of KES30,000 to buy more of the goods sold at the shop.  In the future, he wants to expand the business and be a wholesaler.  Joseph is married and has a three year old daugther.  He describes himself as hardworking, honest and dedicated to his work.

loans.use: To add stock of household goods.

loans.name: Julia

texts.es:
Nuestra socia JULIA tiene 26 años, es conviviente y tiene una hija llamada Nicol que tiene 5 años que estudia en el jardín. La socia alterna sus actividades del hogar con la preparación de tortas, bocaditos a pedido. Sus clientes de la socia le hacen el pedido de 10 tortas a 15 tortas por día para eventos como cumpleaños, bautizos y matrimonios.  Ya es un año que tiene el negocio y le ha ido muy bien, gracias a todo el empeño que pone en su trabajo. Nuestra socia es una madre trabajadora y emprendedora que saca adelante a su familia. La socia requiere el préstamo para comprar más insumos como harina, azúcar, leche, mantequilla y muchas cosas más. 

La socia es natural de la ciudad del Cusco y pertenece al Banco Comunal “FUENTE DE VIDA” de la Asociación Arariwa. Cusco antiguamente, fue la capital del Imperio Inca y una de las ciudades más importantes del Virreinato del Perú. Declarada Patrimonio de la Humanidad y capital arqueológica de América 

La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Our partner Julia is 26 years old, a live-in partner, and has a daughter named Nicol, who is five years old and in kindergarten. She alternates her household chores with the preparation of cakes and snacks by request. Her clients order 10 to 15 cakes a day for events such as birthday parties, baptisms, and weddings. She has had this business for a year now, and it has gone very well, thanks to all of the effort she puts forth in her work. Our partner is a hard-working and enterprising mother who is helping her family get ahead. She requires this loan to purchase more supplies, such as flour, sugar, milk, butter, and many other things. She is a native of the city of Cusco and belongs to the communal bank "Fuente de Vida" of the Asociacion Arariwa. In the past, Cusco was the capital of the Inca Empire and one of the most important cities of the viceroyalty of Peru. It was declared a patrimony of humanity and archaeological capital of America. Our partner is grateful for the opportunity provided through this medium, and likewise is committed to fulfill her payment in the established time frame.

Translated from Spanish by Mark Broscoe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase supplies such as flour, sugar, milk, butter, and more

loans.name: Madeline

texts.en:
Madeline C., 40 years old, manages a piggery. She raises pigs and sells them after four months. Everyday, she cleans the barn and feed her pigs. She started her business in 1990 and she has been doing the same business until now, because for her, it is a very feasible business.

She would like to ask for a loan of Php 8,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy piglets and feed for her pigs. The loan will really be of great help to sustain her business and have regular income for her family.

loans.use: To buy piglets and feed

loans.name: Florentina

texts.es:
Florentina tiene 55 años, vive con sus 2 hijos en la casa que heredó de sus padres.
Desde hace 3 años se dedica a la venta de gaseosas al por mayor y desde hace un año, ella misma elabora y embotella sus bebidas. Para ello viaja con frecuencia a las ciudades donde distribuye su producto. La época de verano es cuando tiene mayor demanda y puede obtener mejores ganancias, por lo que se abastece muy bien para esa temporada. 
El deseo de Florentina es poder vender sus bebidas en otras ciudades, para ello seguirá trabajando arduamente para incrementar su capital de trabajo.

Es la sexta oportunidad en que tiene un crédito con MFP, ella es muy responsable con el pago de sus cuotas y en esta oportunidad renueva su compromiso de responsabilidad. El dinero que ahora solicita lo utilizará en la compra de los insumos para la fabricación de su producto; tales como azúcar, esencia, saborizante, entre otros.
texts.en:
Florentina is 55 years old and lives with her two children in the house that she inherited from her parents. For the last three years she has been selling soda in bulk; and this last year she herself has been making and bottling the beverages. In this respect, she frequently travels to cities where she distributes her products. Summer is the time when demand is greatest and she can earn more, so she stocks up well for that season. It is Florentina's wish to be able to sell her drinks in other cities, and for that she will keep working hard to increase her capital. This is her sixth loan from Kiva Field Partner, Microfinanzas Prisma (MFP). Florentina is very responsible when it comes to making the loan repayments and this opportunity is renewing her commitment to responsibility. She will use the money she is now requesting to buy ingredients for making her drinks, such as sugar, essences and flavorings.

Translated from Spanish by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy ingredients to make beverages

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Marlene

texts.es:
Marlene tiene 35 años, vive con su esposo y sus 3 hijos en una casa arrendada.
Desde hace 3 años se dedica al comercio, anteriormente elaboraba y vendía prendas tejidas a mano, pero ahora (desde hace un año) ha empezado a vender artículos según la temporada y la demanda de las personas. Por ejemplo; cuando es época escolar vende cuadernos, lapiceros y colores y en época navideña vende juguetes.
Su modalidad de venta es al crédito, sus clientes separan el articulo y cada día pagan un porcentaje del precio total, cuando terminan de cancelar les da el articulo, esto le ha permitido obtener mayores ganancias y la facilidad de pago para sus clientes.

Esta es la tercera vez que tiene un crédito con MFP, ella es muy responsable en sus pagos, por lo que fue considerada para renovar su crédito en su banco comunal. El dinero que ahora solicita lo utilizará en la compra de más artículos para la época navideña como juguetes y adornos.
texts.en:
Marlene is 35 years old and lives with her huband and their three children in a furnished house. She has been in business for three years; initially she used to produce and sell hand-made clothes, but since last year she has started a seasonal business. For instance, during the school year she sells notebooks, pencils and color pens, while during the Christmas season she sells toys. She sells on credit: her customers choose the item and pay rates until they have fully paid the price and then they receive the item. This way she is making more revenue and can offer an easier way to pay to her customers. This is her third loan with MFP and she has always fully repaid. For this reason she was considered for a new loan in her commune bank. This loan is helping her to buy supplies for the Christmas season, such as toys and decorations.

Translated from Spanish by MONICA URBAN, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase stocks

loans.name: Nelly Aurora

texts.es:
Nelly A. de 40 años de edad, vive en el sector ubicado en la Perimetral de Guayaquil, Nelly esperaba la ayuda de su hijo mayor y de su ex esposo para poder solventar los gastos familiares, pero ya no quería ser molestia porque cada uno tenia su familia decidió comenzar a vender colas, una vez que hizo clientes las personas le pedían también ropa a domicilio y comenzó a realizar esta actividad.   

Ahora Nelly comprar y vende colas y ropa las 24 horas a sus clientes de puerta a puerta, ella vende pantalones, blusas, bebidas, tiene 2 hijos. 

Con el préstamo quiere comprar más pantalones, blusas, colas para poder agrandar mas su negocio, en el futuro quiere poner un bazar y con esto arreglar su casa porque algunas partes siguen siendo de caña.
texts.en:
Nelly A. is 40 and lives in an area along the Perimetral road in Guayaquil. She was hoping her ex-husband and son would be able to help with her household income issues. She didn't want to bother them, though, because they had families of their own, so she decided to start selling sodas. Once she was up and running, her customers wanted her to offer clothing door-to-door, too, so she began doing that. Now Nelly buys sodas and clothing, including pants and shirts, and sells them door-to-door to her customers twenty-four hours a day. She has two children. She wants to use her loan to buy more pants, shirts, and sodas in order to expand her business. In the future she would like to have a store and use the income to fix up her house because parts of it are falling apart.

Translated from Spanish by Jill Heske, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Pants and sodas

loans.name: Juan

texts.es:
